<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Frank_Sinatra skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Frank Sinatra</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="dablink">"Sinatra" redirects here. For other uses, see <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sinatra_(disambiguation)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sinatra (disambiguation) (page does not exist)">Sinatra (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_mdy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use mdy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use mdy dates</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_musical_artist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox musical artist (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox musical artist</a>
<b>Francis Albert </b>"<b>Frank</b>"<b> Sinatra</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a>; December 12, 1915 – May 14, 1998)<sup id="cite_ref-PSCemDis_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PSCemDis-1">[1]</a></sup> was an American singer and film actor. Beginning his musical career in the <a href="/wiki/Swing_era" title="Swing era">swing era</a> as a boy singer with <a href="/wiki/Harry_James" title="Harry James">Harry James</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tommy_Dorsey" title="Tommy Dorsey">Tommy Dorsey</a>, Sinatra found success as a solo artist from the early to mid-1940s after being signed by <a href="/wiki/Columbia_Records" title="Columbia Records">Columbia Records</a> in 1943. Being the idol of the "<a href="/wiki/Bobby_soxer" title="Bobby soxer">bobby soxers</a>", he released his first album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Voice_of_Frank_Sinatra&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Voice of Frank Sinatra (page does not exist)">The Voice of Frank Sinatra</a></i> in 1946. His professional career had stalled by the early 1950s, but it was reborn in 1953 after he won the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor (page does not exist)">Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor</a> for his performance in <i><a href="/wiki/From_Here_to_Eternity" title="From Here to Eternity">From Here to Eternity</a></i>. He signed with <a href="/wiki/Capitol_Records" title="Capitol Records">Capitol Records</a> in 1953 and released several critically lauded albums (such as <i><a href="/wiki/In_the_Wee_Small_Hours" title="In the Wee Small Hours">In the Wee Small Hours</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Songs_for_Swingin%27_Lovers!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Songs for Swingin' Lovers! (page does not exist)">Songs for Swingin' Lovers!</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Come_Fly_with_Me_(Frank_Sinatra_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Come Fly with Me (Frank Sinatra album) (page does not exist)">Come Fly with Me</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Frank_Sinatra_Sings_for_Only_the_Lonely&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frank Sinatra Sings for Only the Lonely (page does not exist)">Only the Lonely</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nice_%27n%27_Easy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nice 'n' Easy (page does not exist)">Nice 'n' Easy</a></i>). Sinatra left Capitol to found his own record label, <a href="/wiki/Reprise_Records" title="Reprise Records">Reprise Records</a> in 1961 (finding success with albums such as <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ring-a-Ding-Ding!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ring-a-Ding-Ding! (page does not exist)">Ring-a-Ding-Ding!</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sinatra_at_the_Sands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sinatra at the Sands (page does not exist)">Sinatra at the Sands</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Francis_Albert_Sinatra_%26_Antonio_Carlos_Jobim&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Francis Albert Sinatra &amp; Antonio Carlos Jobim (page does not exist)">Francis Albert Sinatra &amp; Antonio Carlos Jobim</a></i>), toured internationally, was a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Rat_Pack" title="Rat Pack">Rat Pack</a> and fraternized with celebrities and statesmen, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_F._Kennedy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John F. Kennedy (page does not exist)">John F. Kennedy</a>.
</p><p>Sinatra turned 50 in 1965, recorded the retrospective <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=September_of_My_Years&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="September of My Years (page does not exist)">September of My Years</a></i>, starred in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Emmy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Emmy (page does not exist)">Emmy</a>-winning television special <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Frank_Sinatra:_A_Man_and_His_Music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frank Sinatra: A Man and His Music (page does not exist)">Frank Sinatra: A Man and His Music</a></i>, and scored hits with "<a href="/wiki/Strangers_in_the_Night" title="Strangers in the Night">Strangers in the Night</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=My_Way_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="My Way (song) (page does not exist)">My Way</a>". With sales of his music dwindling and after appearing in several poorly received films, Sinatra retired for the first time in 1971. Two years later, however, he came out of retirement and from 1973 recorded several albums, scoring a Top 40 hit with "<a href="/wiki/Theme_from_New_York,_New_York" title="Theme from New York, New York">(Theme From) New York, New York</a>" in 1980. Using his <a href="/wiki/Las_Vegas_Valley" title="Las Vegas Valley">Las Vegas</a> shows as a home base, he toured both within the United States and internationally, until a short time before his death in 1998. Sinatra also forged a highly successful career as a film actor. After winning Best Supporting Actor in 1953, he also garnered a nomination for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_Award_for_Best_Actor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy Award for Best Actor (page does not exist)">Best Actor</a> for <i><a href="/wiki/The_Man_with_the_Golden_Arm" title="The Man with the Golden Arm">The Man with the Golden Arm</a></i>, and critical acclaim for his performance in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Manchurian_Candidate_(1962_film)" title="The Manchurian Candidate (1962 film)">The Manchurian Candidate</a></i>. He also starred in such musicals as <i><a href="/wiki/High_Society_(1956_film)" title="High Society (1956 film)">High Society</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Pal_Joey_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pal Joey (film) (page does not exist)">Pal Joey</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Guys_and_Dolls_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Guys and Dolls (film) (page does not exist)">Guys and Dolls</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=On_the_Town_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="On the Town (film) (page does not exist)">On the Town</a></i>.
</p><p>Sinatra is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_music_artists" title="List of best-selling music artists">best-selling artists of all time</a>. He was honored at the <a href="/wiki/Kennedy_Center_Honors" title="Kennedy Center Honors">Kennedy Center Honors</a> in 1983 and was awarded the <a href="/wiki/Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom" title="Presidential Medal of Freedom">Presidential Medal of Freedom</a> by <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> in 1985 and the <a href="/wiki/Congressional_Gold_Medal" title="Congressional Gold Medal">Congressional Gold Medal</a> in 1997. Sinatra was also the recipient of eleven <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grammy Awards (page does not exist)">Grammy Awards</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Trustees_Award" title="Grammy Trustees Award">Grammy Trustees Award</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Legend_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grammy Legend Award (page does not exist)">Grammy Legend Award</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Lifetime_Achievement_Award" title="Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award">Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award</a>.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span></h2>
<p>Born on December 12, 1915, in <a href="/wiki/Hoboken,_New_Jersey" title="Hoboken, New Jersey">Hoboken, New Jersey</a>, Frank Sinatra was the first and only child of Italian immigrants Natalina Garaventa<sup id="cite_ref-Summers_Swan_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Summers_Swan-2">[2]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anthony_Martin_Sinatra&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anthony Martin Sinatra (page does not exist)">Antonino Martino Sinatra</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Summers_Swan_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Summers_Swan-2">[2]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Verify_credibility&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Verify credibility (page does not exist)">Template:Verify credibility</a> and was raised Roman Catholic.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> In his book <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Try_and_Stop_Me_(book)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Try and Stop Me (book) (page does not exist)">Try and Stop Me</a></i> (p.&#160;218), American publisher and writer <a href="/wiki/Bennett_Cerf" title="Bennett Cerf">Bennett Cerf</a> says that Sinatra's father was a lightweight boxer who fought under the name Marty O'Brien and served with the Hoboken Fire Department as a Captain. His mother, known as Dolly, was influential in the neighborhood and in local <a href="/w/index.php?title=Democratic_Party_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Democratic Party (United States) (page does not exist)">Democratic Party</a> circles, but also ran an illegal abortion business that provided services for free, from her home; she was arrested several times and convicted twice for this offense.<sup id="cite_ref-Summers_Swan_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Summers_Swan-2">[2]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> During the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Depression&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Depression (page does not exist)">Great Depression</a>, Dolly nevertheless provided money to her son for outings with friends and expensive clothes.<sup id="cite_ref-Kelley_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kelley-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sinatra left high school without graduating,<sup id="cite_ref-Summers_Swan_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Summers_Swan-2">[2]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> having attended only 47 days before being expelled because of his rowdy conduct. In 1938, Sinatra was arrested for adultery and seduction, a criminal offense at the time.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> For his livelihood, he worked as a delivery boy at the <i>Jersey Observer</i> newspaper,<sup id="cite_ref-Summers_Swan_2-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Summers_Swan-2">[2]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> and later as a riveter at the Tietjen and Lang shipyard,<sup id="cite_ref-Summers_Swan_2-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Summers_Swan-2">[2]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> but music was Sinatra's main interest, and he listened carefully to <a href="/wiki/Big_band" title="Big band">big band</a> jazz.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:R&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:R (page does not exist)">Template:R</a> He began singing for tips at the age of eight, standing on top of the bar at a local nightclub in Hoboken. Sinatra began singing professionally as a teenager in the 1930s,<sup id="cite_ref-Summers_Swan_2-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Summers_Swan-2">[2]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> although he <a href="/wiki/Learning_music_by_ear" title="Learning music by ear">learned music by ear</a> and never learned how to read music.<sup id="cite_ref-obrien20110210_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-obrien20110210-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1935.E2.80.9340:_Start_of_career.2C_work_with_Harry_James_and_Tommy_Dorsey">1935–40: Start of career, work with Harry James and Tommy Dorsey</span></h3>
<p>Sinatra got his first break in 1935 when his mother persuaded a local singing group, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frank_Sinatra_and_the_3_Flashes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frank Sinatra and the 3 Flashes (page does not exist)">The Three Flashes</a>, to let him join. With Sinatra, the group became known as the Hoboken Four,<sup id="cite_ref-mtv_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mtv-8">[8]</a></sup> and they sufficiently impressed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Edward_Bowes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Edward Bowes (page does not exist)">Edward Bowes</a>. After appearing on his show, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Major_Bowes_Amateur_Hour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Major Bowes Amateur Hour (page does not exist)">Major Bowes Amateur Hour</a></i>, they attracted 40,000 votes and won first prize – a six-month contract to perform on stage and radio across the United States.
</p><p>Sinatra left the Hoboken Four and returned home in late 1935. His mother secured him a job as a singing waiter and <a href="/wiki/Master_of_ceremonies" title="Master of ceremonies">MC</a> at the Rustic Cabin in <a href="/wiki/Englewood_Cliffs,_New_Jersey" title="Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey">Englewood Cliffs</a>, New Jersey, for which he was paid $15 a week.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p><p>On March 18, 1939, Sinatra made a demo recording of a song called "Our Love", with the Frank Mane band. The record has "Frank Sinatra" signed on the front. The bandleader kept the original record in a safe for nearly 60 years.<sup id="cite_ref-Summers_Swan_2-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Summers_Swan-2">[2]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> In June, <a href="/wiki/Harry_James" title="Harry James">Harry James</a> hired Sinatra on a one-year contract of $75 a week.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> It was with the James band that Sinatra released his first commercial record "From the Bottom of My Heart" in July 1939<sup id="cite_ref-pc22_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pc22-11">[11]</a></sup>— US Brunswick No.&#160;8443 and UK Columbia #DB2150.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> In September 1940, Sinatra, after playing with Tommy Dorsey at <a href="/wiki/Old_Orchard_Beach,_Maine#The_Pier" title="Old Orchard Beach, Maine">Old Orchard Beach Pier</a>, surprised nightclubbers in Portland, Maine, by turning up at the Morocco Lounge. "It was way before he became famous." <sup id="cite_ref-Portland_Magazine_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Portland_Magazine-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>Fewer than 8,000 copies of "From the Bottom of My Heart" (Brunswick No.&#160;8443) were sold, making the record a very rare find that is sought after by record collectors worldwide. Sinatra released ten commercial tracks with James through 1939, including "All or Nothing At All" which had weak sales on its initial release, but then sold millions of copies when re-released by Columbia at the height of Sinatra's popularity a few years later.<sup id="cite_ref-rollingstone_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rollingstone-14">[14]</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 1939, in a meeting at the Palmer House in Chicago, Sinatra was asked by bandleader <a href="/wiki/Tommy_Dorsey" title="Tommy Dorsey">Tommy Dorsey</a> to join his band as a replacement for Jack Leonard (the vocalist, not to be confused with the comedian Jack E. Leonard), who had recently left to launch a solo career. This meeting was a turning point in Sinatra's career. By signing with Dorsey's band, one of the hottest at the time, he greatly increased his visibility with the American public. Though Sinatra was still under contract with James, James recognized the opportunity Dorsey offered and graciously released Sinatra from his contract. Sinatra recognized his debt to James throughout his life and upon hearing of James' death in 1983, stated: "he [James] is the one that made it all possible."<sup id="cite_ref-Nancy_1986_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nancy_1986-15">[15]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>On January 26, 1940, Sinatra made his first public appearance with the Dorsey band at the Coronado Theater in Rockford, Illinois.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> In his first year with Dorsey, Sinatra released more than forty songs, with "I'll Never Smile Again" topping the charts for twelve weeks beginning in mid-July.<sup id="cite_ref-Summers_Swan_2-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Summers_Swan-2">[2]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>Sinatra's relationship with Tommy Dorsey was troubled, because of their contract, which awarded Dorsey one-third of Sinatra's lifetime earnings in the entertainment industry. In January 1942, Sinatra recorded his first solo sessions without the Dorsey band (but with Dorsey's arranger <a href="/wiki/Axel_Stordahl" title="Axel Stordahl">Axel Stordahl</a> and with Dorsey's approval). These sessions were released commercially on the Bluebird label. Sinatra left the Dorsey band in late 1942 in an incident that started rumors of Sinatra's involvement with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=American_Mafia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American Mafia (page does not exist)">Mafia</a>. A story appeared in the Hearst newspapers that mobster and Sinatra's Godfather <a href="/wiki/Willie_Moretti" title="Willie Moretti">Willie Moretti</a> coerced Dorsey to let Sinatra out of his contract for a few thousand dollars, and was fictionalized in the book and movie <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Johnny_Fontane&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Johnny Fontane (page does not exist)">The Godfather</a></i>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:R&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:R (page does not exist)">Template:R</a> According to Nancy Sinatra's biography, the Hearst rumors were started because of Frank's Democratic politics. In fact, the contract was bought out by <a href="/wiki/MCA_Inc." title="MCA Inc.">MCA</a> founder <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jules_C._Stein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jules C. Stein (page does not exist)">Jules C. Stein</a> for $75,000.<sup id="cite_ref-Nancy_1986_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nancy_1986-15">[15]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1940.E2.80.9350:_Sinatramania_and_decline_of_career">1940–50: Sinatramania and decline of career</span></h3>
<p>In May 1941, Sinatra was at the top of the male singer polls in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Billboard_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Billboard (magazine) (page does not exist)">Billboard</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Down_Beat" title="Down Beat">Down Beat</a></i> magazines.<sup id="cite_ref-Summers_Swan_2-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Summers_Swan-2">[2]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> His appeal to <a href="/wiki/Bobby_soxer" title="Bobby soxer">bobby soxers</a>, as teenage girls of that time were called, revealed a whole new audience for popular music, which had been recorded mainly for adults up to that time.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</p><p>On December 30, 1942, Sinatra made a "legendary opening" at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Paramount_Theatre_(New_York_City)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Paramount Theatre (New York City) (page does not exist)">Paramount Theater</a> in New York. <a href="/wiki/Jack_Benny" title="Jack Benny">Jack Benny</a> later said, "I thought the goddamned building was going to cave in. I never heard such a commotion&#160;... All this for a fellow I never heard of." When Sinatra returned to the Paramount in October 1944, 35,000 fans caused a near riot outside the venue because they were not allowed in.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:R&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:R (page does not exist)">Template:R</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Frank_Sinatra_by_Gottlieb_c1947-_2.jpg" title="File:Frank Sinatra by Gottlieb c1947- 2.jpg">File:Frank Sinatra by Gottlieb c1947- 2.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sinatra in 1947, at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Liederkranz_Hall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Liederkranz Hall (page does not exist)">Liederkranz Hall</a> in New York</div></div></div>
<p>During the <a href="/w/index.php?title=1942%E2%80%9344_musicians%27_strike&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1942–44 musicians' strike (page does not exist)">musicians' strike of 1942–44</a>, <a href="/wiki/Columbia_Records" title="Columbia Records">Columbia</a> re-released Harry James and Sinatra's version of "<a href="/w/index.php?title=All_or_Nothing_at_All&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="All or Nothing at All (page does not exist)">All or Nothing at All</a>" (music by Arthur Altman and lyrics by Jack Lawrence), recorded in August 1939 and released before Sinatra had made a name for himself. The original release did not even mention the vocalist's name. When the recording was re–released in 1943 with Sinatra's name prominently displayed, the record was on the best–selling list for 18 weeks and reached number 2 on June 2, 1943.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sinatra signed with <a href="/wiki/Columbia_Records" title="Columbia Records">Columbia</a> on June 1, 1943, as a solo artist, and he initially had great success, particularly during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=1942%E2%80%9344_musicians%27_strike&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1942–44 musicians' strike (page does not exist)">1942–44 musicians' strike</a>. Although no new records had been issued during the strike, he had been performing on the radio (on <i><a href="/wiki/Your_Hit_Parade" title="Your Hit Parade">Your Hit Parade</a></i>), and on stage. Columbia wanted new recordings of their growing star as quickly as possible, so Sinatra convinced them to hire <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alec_Wilder&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alec Wilder (page does not exist)">Alec Wilder</a> as arranger and conductor for several sessions with a vocal group called the Bobby Tucker Singers. These first sessions were on June 7, June 22, August 5, and November 10, 1943. Of the nine songs recorded during these sessions, seven charted on the best–selling list.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sinatra did not serve in the military during World War II. On December 11, 1943, he was classified <a href="/w/index.php?title=Class_1-A&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Class 1-A (page does not exist)">4-F</a> ("Registrant not acceptable for military service") for a perforated eardrum by his draft board. Additionally, an <a href="/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation" title="Federal Bureau of Investigation">FBI</a> report on Sinatra, released in 1998, showed that the doctors had also written that he was a "neurotic" and "not acceptable material from a psychiatric standpoint." This was omitted from his record to avoid "undue unpleasantness for both the selectee and the induction service."<sup id="cite_ref-SantopietroT-SinH-2008_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SantopietroT-SinH-2008-20">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NewtonM-TFBIE-2003_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NewtonM-TFBIE-2003-21">[21]</a></sup> Active-duty servicemen, like journalist <a href="/wiki/William_Manchester" title="William Manchester">William Manchester</a>, said of Sinatra, "I think Frank Sinatra was the most hated man of World War II, much more than <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adolf_Hitler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adolf Hitler (page does not exist)">Hitler</a>", because Sinatra was back home making all of that money and being shown in photographs surrounded by beautiful women.<sup id="cite_ref-Kelley_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kelley-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> His exemption would resurface throughout his life and cause him grief when he had to defend himself.<sup id="cite_ref-SantopietroT-SinH-2008_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SantopietroT-SinH-2008-20">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> There were accusations, including some from noted columnist <a href="/wiki/Walter_Winchell" title="Walter Winchell">Walter Winchell</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> that Sinatra paid $40,000 to avoid the service – but the FBI found no evidence of this.<sup id="cite_ref-NewtonM-TFBIE-2003_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NewtonM-TFBIE-2003-21">[21]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p><p>In her book "Over Here, Over There" with Bill Gilbert, Maxene Andrews recalled when Sinatra entertained the troops during an overseas USO tour with comedian <a href="/wiki/Phil_Silvers" title="Phil Silvers">Phil Silvers</a> during the war, observing, "I guess they just had a wing-ding, whatever it was. Sinatra demanded his own plane. But Bing [Crosby] said, 'Don't demand anything. Just go over there and sing your hearts out.' So, we did."<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> Sinatra worked frequently with the very popular <a href="/wiki/The_Andrews_Sisters" title="The Andrews Sisters">Andrews Sisters</a>, both on radio in the 1940s, appearing as guests on each other's shows, as well as on many shows broadcast to troops via the <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_Radio_Service" title="Armed Forces Radio Service" class="mw-redirect">Armed Forces Radio Service</a> (AFRS). He appeared as special guest on a rare pilot episode of the sisters' ABC <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Eight-to-the-Bar_Ranch&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eight-to-the-Bar Ranch (page does not exist)">Eight-to-the-Bar Ranch</a></i> series at the end of 1944, and returned for another much funnier guest stint a few months later, while the trio in turn guested on his <a href="/w/index.php?title=Songs_by_Sinatra&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Songs by Sinatra (page does not exist)">Songs by Sinatra</a> series on CBS, to the delight of an audience filled with screaming bobby-soxers. Patty, Maxene, and LaVerne also teamed with Frankie when they appeared three times as guests on Sinatra's CBS television show in the early-1950s. Maxene once told Joe Franklin during a 1979 WWOR-AM Radio interview that Sinatra was "a peculiar man," with the ability to act indifferent towards her at times.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1945, Sinatra co-starred with <a href="/wiki/Gene_Kelly" title="Gene Kelly">Gene Kelly</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/Anchors_Aweigh_(film)" title="Anchors Aweigh (film)">Anchors Aweigh</a></i>. That same year, he was loaned out to RKO to star in a short film titled <i><a href="/wiki/The_House_I_Live_In_(1945_film)" title="The House I Live In (1945 film)">The House I Live In</a></i>. Directed by <a href="/wiki/Mervyn_LeRoy" title="Mervyn LeRoy">Mervyn LeRoy</a>, this film on tolerance and <a href="/wiki/Racial_equality" title="Racial equality">racial equality</a> earned a special <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy Award (page does not exist)">Academy Award</a> shared among Sinatra and those who brought the film to the screen, along with a special <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe" title="Golden Globe" class="mw-redirect">Golden Globe</a> for "Promoting Good Will". 1946 saw the release of his first album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Voice_of_Frank_Sinatra&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Voice of Frank Sinatra (page does not exist)">The Voice of Frank Sinatra</a></i>, and the debut of his own weekly radio show. By the end of 1948, Sinatra felt that his career was stalling, something that was confirmed when he slipped to No. 4 on <i><a href="/wiki/Down_Beat" title="Down Beat">Down Beat</a>'</i>s annual poll of most popular singers (behind <a href="/wiki/Billy_Eckstine" title="Billy Eckstine">Billy Eckstine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frankie_Laine" title="Frankie Laine">Frankie Laine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bing_Crosby" title="Bing Crosby">Bing Crosby</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-Summers_Swan_2-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Summers_Swan-2">[2]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>The year 1949 saw an upswing, as Frank co-starred with Gene Kelly in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Take_Me_Out_to_the_Ball_Game_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Take Me Out to the Ball Game (film) (page does not exist)">Take Me Out to the Ball Game</a></i>. It was well received critically and became a major commercial success. That same year, Sinatra teamed up with Kelly for a third time in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=On_the_Town_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="On the Town (film) (page does not exist)">On the Town</a></i>. Starting in September 1949, the BBD&amp;O advertising agency produced a radio series starring Sinatra for its client Lucky Strike called "Light Up Time" <a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.watertownology.com/lightup">[1]</a>—some 176 15-minute shows which featured Frank and Dorothy Kirsten singing—which lasted through to May 1950.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1950.E2.80.9360:_Rebirth_of_career.2C_Capitol_concept_albums">1950–60: Rebirth of career, Capitol concept albums</span></h3>
<p>After two years' absence, Sinatra returned to the concert stage on January 12, 1950, in <a href="/wiki/Hartford,_Connecticut" title="Hartford, Connecticut">Hartford, Connecticut</a>. His voice suffered and he experienced hemorrhaging of his vocal cords on stage at the <a href="/wiki/Copacabana_(nightclub)" title="Copacabana (nightclub)">Copacabana</a> on April 26, 1950.<sup id="cite_ref-Kelley_5-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kelley-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> Sinatra's career and appeal to new teen audiences declined as he moved into his mid-30s.
</p><p>This was a period of serious self-doubt about the trajectory of his career. In February 1951, he was walking through <a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">Times Square</a>, past the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Paramount_Theatre_(New_York_City)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Paramount Theatre (New York City) (page does not exist)">Paramount Theatre</a>, keystone venue of his earlier phenomenal success. The Paramount marquee glowed in announcement of <a href="/wiki/Eddie_Fisher_(singer)" title="Eddie Fisher (singer)">Eddie Fisher</a> in concert. Swarms of teen-age girls had gathered in frenzy, swooning over the current singing idol. For Sinatra this public display of enthusiasm for Fisher validated a fear he had harbored in his own mind for a long time. The Sinatra star had fallen; the shouts of "Frankieee" were echoes of the past. Agitated and disconsolate he rushed home, closed his kitchen door, turned on the gas and laid his head on top of the stove. A friend returned to the apartment not long after to find Sinatra lying on the floor sobbing out the melodrama of his life, proclaiming his failure was so complete he could not even commit suicide.<sup id="cite_ref-Kaplan_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kaplan-28">[28]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>In September 1951, Sinatra made his Las Vegas debut at the <a href="/wiki/Desert_Inn" title="Desert Inn">Desert Inn</a>, and he became a prominent figure on the Las Vegas scene <a href="/w/index.php?title=Las_Vegas_in_the_1950s&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Las Vegas in the 1950s (page does not exist)">throughout the 1950s</a> and 1960s. A month later, the second season of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Frank_Sinatra_Show_(CBS_TV_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Frank Sinatra Show (CBS TV series) (page does not exist)">The Frank Sinatra Show</a></i> began on <a href="/w/index.php?title=CBS_Television&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="CBS Television (page does not exist)">CBS Television</a>. Ultimately, Sinatra did not find the success on television for which he had hoped. The persona he presented to the TV audience was not that of a performer easily welcomed into homes. He projected an arrogance not compatible with the type of cozy congeniality that played well on the small screen.<sup id="cite_ref-Kaplan_28-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kaplan-28">[28]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>His last studio recording for Columbia was made in New York <sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> in September 1952, "Why Try To Change Me Now", with orchestra arranged and conducted by Percy Faith. Columbia and MCA dropped him later in 1952.
</p><p>The rebirth of Sinatra's career began with the eve-of-<a href="/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor" title="Attack on Pearl Harbor">Pearl Harbor</a> drama <i><a href="/wiki/From_Here_to_Eternity" title="From Here to Eternity">From Here to Eternity</a></i> (1953), for which he won an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor (page does not exist)">Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor</a>. This role and performance marked a turnaround in Sinatra's career: after several years of critical and commercial decline, becoming an Oscar-winning actor helped him regain his position as the top recording artist in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1953, Sinatra starred in the NBC radio program <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rocky_Fortune&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rocky Fortune (page does not exist)">Rocky Fortune</a></i>. His character, Rocco Fortunato (aka Rocky Fortune) was a temp worker for the Gridley Employment Agency who stumbled into crime-solving by way of the odd jobs to which he was dispatched. The series <sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> aired on NBC radio Tuesday nights from October 1953 to March 1954, following the network's crime drama hit <i><a href="/wiki/Dragnet_(series)" title="Dragnet (series)">Dragnet</a></i>. During the final months of the show, just before the 1954 Oscars, it became a running gag that Sinatra would manage to work the phrase "from here to eternity" into each episode, a reference to his Oscar-nominated performance.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>Also in 1953, Sinatra signed with <a href="/wiki/Capitol_Records" title="Capitol Records">Capitol Records</a>, where he worked with many of the finest musical arrangers of the era, most notably <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Riddle" title="Nelson Riddle">Nelson Riddle</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-pc22_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pc22-11">[11]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gordon_Jenkins" title="Gordon Jenkins">Gordon Jenkins</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Billy_May" title="Billy May">Billy May</a>. With a series of albums featuring darker emotional material, Sinatra reinvented himself, including <i><a href="/wiki/In_the_Wee_Small_Hours" title="In the Wee Small Hours">In the Wee Small Hours</a></i> (1955)—Sinatra's first 12" LP and his second collaboration with Nelson Riddle—<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Where_Are_You%3F_(Frank_Sinatra_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Where Are You? (Frank Sinatra album) (page does not exist)">Where Are You?</a></i> (1957) his first album in stereo, with Gordon Jenkins, and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Frank_Sinatra_Sings_for_Only_the_Lonely&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frank Sinatra Sings for Only the Lonely (page does not exist)">Frank Sinatra Sings for Only the Lonely</a></i> (1958). He also incorporated a hipper, "swinging" persona into some of his music, as heard on <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Swing_Easy!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Swing Easy! (page does not exist)">Swing Easy!</a></i> (1954), <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Songs_for_Swingin%27_Lovers!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Songs for Swingin' Lovers! (page does not exist)">Songs for Swingin' Lovers!</a></i> (1956), and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Come_Fly_with_Me_(Frank_Sinatra_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Come Fly with Me (Frank Sinatra album) (page does not exist)">Come Fly With Me</a></i> (1957).
</p><p>By the end of the year, Billboard had named "Young at Heart" Song of the Year; <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Swing_Easy!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Swing Easy! (page does not exist)">Swing Easy!</a></i>, with Nelson Riddle at the helm (his second album for Capitol), was named Album of the Year; and Sinatra was named "Top Male Vocalist" by <i>Billboard</i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Down_Beat" title="Down Beat">Down Beat</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Metronome" title="Metronome">Metronome</a></i>.
</p><p>A third collaboration with Nelson Riddle, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Songs_for_Swingin%27_Lovers!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Songs for Swingin' Lovers! (page does not exist)">Songs for Swingin' Lovers!</a></i>, was both a critical and financial success, featuring a recording of "<a href="/w/index.php?title=I%27ve_Got_You_Under_My_Skin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I've Got You Under My Skin (page does not exist)">I've Got You Under My Skin</a>".
</p><p><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Frank_Sinatra_Sings_for_Only_the_Lonely&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frank Sinatra Sings for Only the Lonely (page does not exist)">Frank Sinatra Sings for Only the Lonely</a></i>, a stark collection of introspective saloon songs and blues-tinged ballads, was a mammoth commercial success, spending 120 weeks on Billboards album chart and peaking at No.&#160;1. Cuts from this LP, such as "Angel Eyes" and "One for My Baby (and One More for the Road)", would remain staples of Sinatra's concerts throughout his life.
</p><p>Through the late fifties, Sinatra frequently criticized rock and roll music, much of it being his reaction to rhythms and attitudes he found alien. In 1958 he lambasted it as "sung, played, and written for the most part by cretinous goons. It manages to be the martial music of every sideburned delinquent on the face of the earth."<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sinatra's 1959 hit "<a href="/w/index.php?title=High_Hopes_(1959_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="High Hopes (1959 song) (page does not exist)">High Hopes</a>" lasted on the Hot 100 for 17 weeks, more than any other Sinatra hit did on that chart, and was a recurring favorite for years on <i><a href="/wiki/Captain_Kangaroo" title="Captain Kangaroo">Captain Kangaroo</a></i>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1960.E2.80.9370:_Ring-a-Ding-Ding.21.2C_Reprise_records.2C_Basie.2C_Jobim.2C_.22My_Way.22">1960–70: <i>Ring-a-Ding-Ding!</i>, Reprise records, Basie, Jobim, "My Way"</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Frank_Sinatra_laughing.jpg" title="File:Frank Sinatra laughing.jpg">File:Frank Sinatra laughing.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Frank Sinatra at Girl's Town Ball in Florida, March 12, 1960</div></div></div>
<p>Sinatra started the 1960s as he ended the 1950s. His first album of the decade, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nice_%27n%27_Easy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nice 'n' Easy (page does not exist)">Nice 'n' Easy</a></i>, topped <i>Billboard</i>'s chart and won critical plaudits. Sinatra grew discontented at Capitol and decided to form his own label, <a href="/wiki/Reprise_Records" title="Reprise Records">Reprise Records</a>. His first album on the label, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ring-a-Ding-Ding!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ring-a-Ding-Ding! (page does not exist)">Ring-a-Ding-Ding!</a></i> (1961), was a major success, peaking at No.4 on <i>Billboard</i> and No.8 in the UK.
</p><p>In 1965, he starred in what was considered one of his most successful films, <i><a href="/wiki/Von_Ryan%27s_Express" title="Von Ryan's Express">Von Ryan's Express</a></i>.  His fourth and final <a href="/wiki/Timex_Group_USA" title="Timex Group USA">Timex</a> TV special was broadcast in March 1960, and earned massive viewing figures. Titled <i>It's Nice to Go Travelling</i>, the show is more commonly known as <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Frank_Sinatra_Timex_Show:_Welcome_Home_Elvis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Frank Sinatra Timex Show: Welcome Home Elvis (page does not exist)">Welcome Home Elvis</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/Elvis_Presley" title="Elvis Presley">Elvis Presley</a>'s appearance after his army discharge was somewhat ironic; Sinatra had been scathing about him in the mid fifties, saying: "His kind of music is deplorable, a rancid smelling aphrodisiac. It fosters almost totally negative and destructive reactions in young people."<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> Presley had responded: "...&#160;[Sinatra] is a great success and a fine actor, but I think he shouldn't have said it&#160;... [rock and roll] is a trend, just the same as he faced when he started years ago."<sup id="cite_ref-Hopkins126_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hopkins126-35">[35]</a></sup> Later, in efforts to maintain his commercial viability, Sinatra recorded Presley's hit "<a href="/wiki/Love_Me_Tender_(song)" title="Love Me Tender (song)">Love Me Tender</a>" as well as works by <a href="/wiki/Paul_Simon" title="Paul Simon">Paul Simon</a> ("<a href="/w/index.php?title=Mrs._Robinson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mrs. Robinson (page does not exist)">Mrs. Robinson</a>"), <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a> ("<a href="/wiki/Something" title="Something">Something</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Yesterday" title="Yesterday">Yesterday</a>"), and <a href="/wiki/Joni_Mitchell" title="Joni Mitchell">Joni Mitchell</a> ("<a href="/w/index.php?title=Both_Sides,_Now&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Both Sides, Now (page does not exist)">Both Sides, Now</a>").<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following on the heels of the film <i>Can Can</i> was <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ocean%27s_11_(1960_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ocean's 11 (1960 film) (page does not exist)">Ocean's 11</a></i>, the movie that became the definitive on-screen outing for "<a href="/wiki/The_Rat_Pack" title="The Rat Pack" class="mw-redirect">The Rat Pack</a>," a group of entertainers led by Sinatra who worked together on a loose basis in films and casino shows featuring <a href="/wiki/Dean_Martin" title="Dean Martin">Dean Martin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sammy_Davis,_Jr." title="Sammy Davis, Jr.">Sammy Davis, Jr.</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Lawford" title="Peter Lawford">Peter Lawford</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Joey_Bishop" title="Joey Bishop">Joey Bishop</a>. Subsequent pictures together included <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sergeants_3&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sergeants 3 (page does not exist)">Sergeants 3</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Robin_and_the_7_Hoods" title="Robin and the 7 Hoods">Robin and the 7 Hoods</a></i>, although the movies' rosters of actors varied slightly according to whom Sinatra happened to be angry with when casting any given film; he replaced <a href="/wiki/Sammy_Davis,_Jr." title="Sammy Davis, Jr.">Sammy Davis, Jr.</a> with <a href="/wiki/Steve_McQueen" title="Steve McQueen">Steve McQueen</a> in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Never_So_Few&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Never So Few (page does not exist)">Never So Few</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/Peter_Lawford" title="Peter Lawford">Peter Lawford</a> with <a href="/wiki/Bing_Crosby" title="Bing Crosby">Bing Crosby</a> in <i>Robin and the 7 Hoods</i>.
</p><p>From his youth, Sinatra displayed sympathy for African Americans and worked both publicly and privately all his life to help them win equal rights. He played a major role in the <a href="/wiki/Desegregation" title="Desegregation">desegregation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Nevada" title="Nevada">Nevada</a> hotels and casinos in the 1960s. On January 27, 1961, Sinatra played a benefit show at <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Hall" title="Carnegie Hall">Carnegie Hall</a> for <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther_King,_Jr." title="Martin Luther King, Jr.">Martin Luther King, Jr.</a> and led his fellow Rat Pack members and Reprise label mates in boycotting hotels and casinos that refused entry to black patrons and performers. He often spoke from the stage on desegregation and repeatedly played benefits on behalf of Dr. King and his movement. According to his son, <a href="/wiki/Frank_Sinatra,_Jr." title="Frank Sinatra, Jr.">Frank Sinatra, Jr.</a>, King sat weeping in the audience at a concert in 1963 as Sinatra sang <i><a href="/wiki/Ol%27_Man_River" title="Ol' Man River">Ol' Man River</a></i>, a song from the musical <i><a href="/wiki/Show_Boat" title="Show Boat">Show Boat</a></i> that is sung by an African-American stevedore.
</p><p>On September 11 and 12, 1961, Sinatra recorded his final songs for Capitol.
</p><p>In 1962, he starred with <a href="/wiki/Janet_Leigh" title="Janet Leigh">Janet Leigh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Laurence_Harvey" title="Laurence Harvey">Laurence Harvey</a> in the political thriller, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Manchurian_Candidate_(1962_film)" title="The Manchurian Candidate (1962 film)">The Manchurian Candidate</a></i>, playing Bennett Marco. That same year, Sinatra and <a href="/wiki/Count_Basie" title="Count Basie">Count Basie</a> collaborated for the album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sinatra-Basie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sinatra-Basie (page does not exist)">Sinatra-Basie</a></i>. This popular and successful release prompted them to rejoin two years later for the follow-up <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=It_Might_as_Well_Be_Swing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="It Might as Well Be Swing (page does not exist)">It Might as Well Be Swing</a></i>, which was arranged by <a href="/wiki/Quincy_Jones" title="Quincy Jones">Quincy Jones</a>. One of Sinatra's more ambitious albums from the mid-1960s, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Concert_Sinatra&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Concert Sinatra (page does not exist)">The Concert Sinatra</a></i>, with a 73-piece symphony orchestra led by Nelson Riddle, was recorded on a motion picture scoring stage with the use of multiple synchronized recording machines that employed 35&#160;mm magnetic film (multi-track tape mastering machines were then limited to 4 tracks, although 3 tracks was more common; an 8 track machine, "The Octopus", had been made as a "one-off" for <a href="/wiki/Les_Paul" title="Les Paul">Les Paul</a> earlier).
</p><p>Sinatra's first live album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sinatra_at_the_Sands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sinatra at the Sands (page does not exist)">Sinatra at the Sands</a></i>, was recorded during January and February 1966 at the <a href="/wiki/Sands_Hotel_and_Casino" title="Sands Hotel and Casino">Sands Hotel and Casino</a> in Las Vegas.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dean_Martin_Show_1958_Dean_Martin_Frank_Sinatra.JPG" title="File:Dean Martin Show 1958 Dean Martin Frank Sinatra.JPG">File:Dean Martin Show 1958 Dean Martin Frank Sinatra.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Dean_Martin" title="Dean Martin">Dean Martin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rat_Pack" title="Rat Pack">Frank Sinatra</a></div></div></div>
<p>In June 1965, Sinatra, <a href="/wiki/Sammy_Davis,_Jr." title="Sammy Davis, Jr.">Sammy Davis, Jr.</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Dean_Martin" title="Dean Martin">Dean Martin</a> played live in <a href="/wiki/St._Louis" title="St. Louis">St. Louis</a> to benefit Dismas House. The <a href="/wiki/Rat_Pack" title="Rat Pack">Rat Pack</a> concert was broadcast live via satellite to numerous movie theaters across America. Released in August 1965 was the Grammy Award–winning album of the year, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=September_of_My_Years&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="September of My Years (page does not exist)">September of My Years</a></i>, containing the single "<a href="/wiki/It_Was_a_Very_Good_Year" title="It Was a Very Good Year">It Was a Very Good Year</a>", which won the Grammy Award for Best Vocal Performance, Male in 1966. A career anthology, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Man_and_His_Music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Man and His Music (page does not exist)">A Man and His Music</a></i>, followed in November, winning Album of the Year at the Grammys in 1966. The TV special, <i>Frank Sinatra: A Man and His Music</i>, garnered both an Emmy award and a <a href="/wiki/Peabody_Award" title="Peabody Award">Peabody Award</a>.
</p><p>In spring, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=That%27s_Life_(Frank_Sinatra_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="That's Life (Frank Sinatra album) (page does not exist)">That's Life</a></i> appeared, with both the single and album becoming Top Ten hits in the US on <i>Billboard'</i>s pop charts. <i><a href="/wiki/Strangers_in_the_Night" title="Strangers in the Night">Strangers in the Night</a></i> went on to top the <i>Billboard</i> and UK pop singles charts, winning the award for Record of the Year at the <a href="/wiki/Grammys" title="Grammys" class="mw-redirect">Grammys</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Strangers_in_the_Night_(Frank_Sinatra_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Strangers in the Night (Frank Sinatra album) (page does not exist)">album of the same name</a> also topped the <i>Billboard</i> chart and reached number 4 in the UK.
</p><p>Sinatra started 1967 with a series of recording sessions with <a href="/wiki/Ant%C3%B4nio_Carlos_Jobim" title="Antônio Carlos Jobim">Antônio Carlos Jobim</a>. Later in the year, a duet with daughter Nancy, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Somethin%27_Stupid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Somethin' Stupid (page does not exist)">Somethin' Stupid</a>", topped the <i>Billboard</i> pop and UK singles charts. In December, Sinatra collaborated with <a href="/wiki/Duke_Ellington" title="Duke Ellington">Duke Ellington</a> on the album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Francis_A._%26_Edward_K.&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Francis A. &amp; Edward K. (page does not exist)">Francis A. &amp; Edward K.</a></i>.
</p><p>During the late 1960s, press agent <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lee_Solters&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lee Solters (page does not exist)">Lee Solters</a> would invite columnists and their spouses into Sinatra's dressing room just before he was about to go on stage. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_Yorker" title="The New Yorker">The New Yorker</a></i> recounted that "the first columnist they tried this on was Larry Fields of the <i><a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Daily_News" title="Philadelphia Daily News">Philadelphia Daily News</a></i>, whose wife fainted when Sinatra kissed her cheek. 'Take care of it, Lee,' Sinatra said, and he was off." The professional relationship Sinatra shared with Solters focused on projects on the west coast while those focused on the east coast were handled by Solters' partner, Sheldon Roskin of Solters/Roskin/Friedman, a well-known firm at the time.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>Back on the small-screen, Sinatra once again worked with Jobim and <a href="/wiki/Ella_Fitzgerald" title="Ella Fitzgerald">Ella Fitzgerald</a> on the TV special, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Man_and_His_Music_%2B_Ella_%2B_Jobim&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Man and His Music + Ella + Jobim (page does not exist)">A Man and His Music + Ella + Jobim</a></i>.
</p><p>With Sinatra in mind, singer-songwriter <a href="/wiki/Paul_Anka" title="Paul Anka">Paul Anka</a> wrote the song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=My_Way_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="My Way (song) (page does not exist)">My Way</a>", inspired from the French "Comme d'habitude" ("As Usual"), composed by <a href="/wiki/Claude_Fran%C3%A7ois" title="Claude François">Claude François</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Revaux" title="Jacques Revaux">Jacques Revaux</a>. "My Way" became more closely identified with him than any other song over his seven decades as a singer even though he reputedly did not care for it. The chorus of <a href="/wiki/Bon_Jovi" title="Bon Jovi">Bon Jovi</a>'s "<a href="/w/index.php?title=It%27s_My_Life_(Bon_Jovi_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="It's My Life (Bon Jovi song) (page does not exist)">It's My Life</a>" (subsequently covered by <a href="/wiki/Paul_Anka" title="Paul Anka">Paul Anka</a> on Rock Swings) references the song in the line "My heart is like an open highway/Like Frankie said, I did it my way".
</p><p><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Watertown_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Watertown (album) (page does not exist)">Watertown</a></i> (1970) was one of Sinatra's most acclaimed concept albums<sup id="cite_ref-Watertown_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Watertown-38">[38]</a></sup> with music by Bob Gaudio (of the Four Seasons) and lyrics by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jake_Holmes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jake Holmes (page does not exist)">Jake Holmes</a>, but it was all but ignored by the public. Selling a mere 30,000 copies in 1970 and reaching a peak chart position of 101, its failure put an end to plans for a television special based on the album. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.watertownology.com">Watertown</a> was one of the only recording sessions having Sinatra sing against pre-recorded tracks vs. a live orchestra
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1970.E2.80.9380:_Retirement_and_comeback">1970–80: Retirement and comeback</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Queen_Farah_of_Persia_and_Frank_Sinatra,_Tehran,_1975.jpg" title="File:Queen Farah of Persia and Frank Sinatra, Tehran, 1975.jpg">File:Queen Farah of Persia and Frank Sinatra, Tehran, 1975.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Empress <a href="/w/index.php?title=Farah_Pahlavi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Farah Pahlavi (page does not exist)">Farah Diba</a> of <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Persia (Iran)</a> and Frank Sinatra, <a href="/wiki/Tehran" title="Tehran">Tehran</a>, 1975</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Andreotti_Sinatra_Nixon.jpg" title="File:Andreotti Sinatra Nixon.jpg">File:Andreotti Sinatra Nixon.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Frank Sinatra, with <a href="/wiki/Giulio_Andreotti" title="Giulio Andreotti">Giulio Andreotti</a> (left), President <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">Richard Nixon</a> and First Lady <a href="/wiki/Pat_Nixon" title="Pat Nixon">Pat Nixon</a> at the White House, 1973</div></div></div>
<p>On November 2, 1970 Sinatra recorded the last songs for Reprise Records before his self-imposed retirement. The final song recorded at the session was written by John Denver and titled "The Game is Over". However, this song was not released officially until <i>The Complete Reprise Studio Recordings</i> suitcase box-set, which went on sale in 1995 to commemorate his 80th birthday.
</p><p>On June 13, 1971 – at a concert in Hollywood to raise money for the Motion Picture and TV Relief Fund – at the age of 55, Sinatra announced that he was retiring, bringing to an end his 36-year career in show business.
</p><p>While he was in retirement, President Richard Nixon asked him to perform at a Young Voters Rally in anticipation of the upcoming campaign. Sinatra obliged and chose to sing "My Kind of Town" for the rally held in Chicago on October 20, 1972. It is the only known public performance he gave during his retirement.
</p><p>In 1973, Sinatra came out of retirement with a television special and album, both entitled <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ol%27_Blue_Eyes_Is_Back&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ol' Blue Eyes Is Back (page does not exist)">Ol' Blue Eyes Is Back</a></i>. The album, arranged by Gordon Jenkins and <a href="/wiki/Don_Costa" title="Don Costa">Don Costa</a>, was a great success, reaching number 13 on <i>Billboard</i> and number 12 in the UK. The TV special was highlighted by a dramatic reading of "<a href="/wiki/Send_in_the_Clowns" title="Send in the Clowns">Send in the Clowns</a>" and a song-and-dance sequence with former co-star Gene Kelly.
</p><p>In January 1974, Sinatra returned to Las Vegas, performing at <a href="/wiki/Caesars_Palace" title="Caesars Palace">Caesars Palace</a> despite vowing in 1970 never to play there again after the manager of the resort, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sanford_Waterman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sanford Waterman (page does not exist)">Sanford Waterman</a>, pulled a gun on him during a heated argument.<sup id="cite_ref-Kelley_5-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kelley-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> In Australia, he caused an uproar by describing journalists there – who were aggressively pursuing his every move and pushing for a press conference – as "fags", "pimps", and "whores". Australian unions representing transport workers, waiters, and journalists went on strike, demanding that Sinatra apologize for his remarks.<sup id="cite_ref-Kelley_5-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kelley-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> Sinatra instead insisted that the journalists apologize for "fifteen years of abuse I have taken from the world press".<sup id="cite_ref-Kelley_5-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kelley-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> The future <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Australia" title="Prime Minister of Australia">Prime Minister of Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bob_Hawke" title="Bob Hawke">Bob Hawke</a>, then the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Council_of_Trade_Unions" title="Australian Council of Trade Unions">Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU)</a> leader, also insisted that Sinatra apologize, and a settlement was eventually reached to the apparent satisfaction of both parties,<sup id="cite_ref-Kelley_5-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kelley-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> Sinatra's final show of his Australian tour was televised.
</p><p>In October 1974, Sinatra appeared at New York City's <a href="/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden" title="Madison Square Garden">Madison Square Garden</a> in a televised concert that was later released as an album under the title <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Main_Event_%E2%80%93_Live&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Main Event – Live (page does not exist)">The Main Event – Live</a></i>. Backing him was bandleader <a href="/wiki/Woody_Herman" title="Woody Herman">Woody Herman</a> and the Young Thundering Herd, who accompanied Sinatra on a European tour later that month. The TV special garnered mostly positive reviews while the album – actually culled from various shows during his comeback tour – was only a moderate success, peaking at No.37 on <i>Billboard</i> and No.30 in the UK.
</p><p>In August 1975, Sinatra held several back-to-back concerts together with the newly-risen singer, <a href="/wiki/John_Denver" title="John Denver">John Denver</a>. Soon they became mutual friends. John Denver later appeared as a guest in the <i>Sinatra and friends</i> TV Special, singing "September Song" together with Sinatra. Sinatra covered the John Denver hits "My Sweet Lady" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Leaving_on_a_Jet_Plane&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leaving on a Jet Plane (page does not exist)">Leaving on a Jet Plane</a>". And, according to Denver, his song "A Baby Just Like You" was written at Sinatra's request.
</p><p>During Labor Day weekend 1976 Sinatra was responsible for reuniting old friends and comedy partners Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis for the first time in nearly twenty years. Sinatra performed for the "Jerry Lewis MDA Telethon" that afternoon and before he performed he brought Dean out on stage.
</p><p>In 1979, in front of the <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_pyramids" title="Egyptian pyramids">Egyptian pyramids</a>, Sinatra performed for <a href="/wiki/Anwar_Sadat" title="Anwar Sadat">Anwar Sadat</a>. Back in Las Vegas, while celebrating 40 years in show business and his 64th birthday, he was awarded the <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Trustees_Award" title="Grammy Trustees Award">Grammy Trustees Award</a> during a party at Caesars Palace.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1980.E2.80.9390:_Trilogy.2C_She_Shot_Me_Down.2C_L.A._Is_My_Lady">1980–90: <i>Trilogy</i>, <i>She Shot Me Down</i>, <i>L.A. Is My Lady</i></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:C10774-23A.jpg" title="File:C10774-23A.jpg">File:C10774-23A.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sinatra sings with then First Lady <a href="/wiki/Nancy_Reagan" title="Nancy Reagan">Nancy Reagan</a> at the <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">White House</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1980, Sinatra's first album in six years was released, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Trilogy:_Past_Present_Future&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trilogy: Past Present Future (page does not exist)">Trilogy: Past Present Future</a></i>, a highly ambitious triple album that found Sinatra recording songs from the past (pre-rock era) and present (rock era and contemporary) that he had overlooked during his career, while 'The Future' was a free-form suite of new songs linked à la musical theater by a theme, in this case, Sinatra pondering over the future. The album garnered six <a href="/wiki/Grammy" title="Grammy" class="mw-redirect">Grammy</a> nominations – winning for best liner notes – and peaked at number 17 on <i>Billboard'</i>s album chart, while spawning yet another song that would become a signature tune, "<a href="/wiki/Theme_from_New_York,_New_York" title="Theme from New York, New York">Theme from New York, New York"</a>, as well as Sinatra's much lauded (second) recording of <a href="/wiki/George_Harrison" title="George Harrison">George Harrison</a>'s "<a href="/wiki/Something" title="Something">Something</a>" (the first was not officially released on an album until 1972's <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Frank_Sinatra%27s_Greatest_Hits,_Vol._2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frank Sinatra's Greatest Hits, Vol. 2 (page does not exist)">Frank Sinatra's Greatest Hits, Vol. 2</a></i>).
</p><p>The following year, Sinatra built on the success of <i>Trilogy</i> with <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=She_Shot_Me_Down&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="She Shot Me Down (page does not exist)">She Shot Me Down</a></i>, an album that revisited the dark tone of his Capitol years, and was praised by critics as a vintage late-period Sinatra. Sinatra would comment that it was "A complete saloon album&#160;... tear-jerkers and cry-in-your-beer kind of things".<sup id="cite_ref-She_Shot_Me_Down_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-She_Shot_Me_Down-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>Also in 1981, Sinatra was embroiled in controversy when he worked a ten-day engagement for $2&#160;million in <a href="/wiki/Sun_City,_North_West" title="Sun City, North West">Sun City</a>, in the internationally unrecognized "independent" <a href="/wiki/Bantustan" title="Bantustan">bantustan</a> <a href="/wiki/Bophuthatswana" title="Bophuthatswana">Bophuthatswana</a>, breaking a cultural boycott against apartheid-era South Africa. (See <a href="/wiki/Artists_United_Against_Apartheid" title="Artists United Against Apartheid">Artists United Against Apartheid</a>) Bophuthatswana's president, <a href="/wiki/Lucas_Mangope" title="Lucas Mangope">Lucas Mangope</a>, awarded Sinatra with Bophuthatswana's highest honor, the Order of the Leopard, and made him an honorary tribal chief.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p><p>He was selected as one of the five recipients of the 1983 <a href="/wiki/Kennedy_Center_Honors" title="Kennedy Center Honors">Kennedy Center Honors</a>, alongside <a href="/wiki/Katherine_Dunham" title="Katherine Dunham">Katherine Dunham</a>, <a href="/wiki/James_Stewart" title="James Stewart">James Stewart</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elia_Kazan" title="Elia Kazan">Elia Kazan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Virgil_Thomson" title="Virgil Thomson">Virgil Thomson</a>. Quoting <a href="/wiki/Henry_James" title="Henry James">Henry James</a> in honoring his old friend, President Reagan said that "art was the shadow of humanity" and that Sinatra had "spent his life casting a magnificent and powerful shadow".<sup id="cite_ref-Kelley_5-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kelley-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>In 1984, Sinatra worked with Quincy Jones for the first time in nearly two decades on the album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=L.A._Is_My_Lady&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="L.A. Is My Lady (page does not exist)">L.A. Is My Lady</a></i>, which was well received critically. The album was a substitute for another Jones project, an album of duets with <a href="/wiki/Lena_Horne" title="Lena Horne">Lena Horne</a>, which had to be abandoned. (Horne developed vocal problems and Sinatra, committed to other engagements, could not wait to record.)
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1990s:_Duets.2C_final_performances">1990s: <i>Duets</i>, final performances</span></h3>
<p>In 1990, Sinatra did a national tour,<sup id="cite_ref-FScnn_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FScnn-41">[41]</a></sup> and was awarded the second "Ella Award" by the Los Angeles–based <a href="/w/index.php?title=Society_of_Singers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Society of Singers (page does not exist)">Society of Singers</a>. At the award ceremony, he performed for the final time with Ella Fitzgerald.<sup id="cite_ref-MichaelFreedland_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MichaelFreedland-42">[42]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>In December, as part of Sinatra's birthday celebrations, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Patrick_Pasculli&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Patrick Pasculli (page does not exist)">Patrick Pasculli</a>, the Mayor of <a href="/wiki/Hoboken,_New_Jersey" title="Hoboken, New Jersey">Hoboken</a>, made a proclamation in his honor, declaring that "no other vocalist in history has sung, swung, crooned, and serenaded into the hearts of the young and old&#160;... as this consummate artist from Hoboken."<sup id="cite_ref-MichaelFreedland_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MichaelFreedland-42">[42]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> The same month Sinatra gave the first show of his Diamond Jubilee Tour at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brendan_Byrne_Arena&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brendan Byrne Arena (page does not exist)">Brendan Byrne Arena</a> in <a href="/wiki/East_Rutherford,_New_Jersey" title="East Rutherford, New Jersey">East Rutherford</a>, New Jersey.
</p><p>In 1993, Sinatra made a surprise return to Capitol and the recording studio for <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Duets_(Frank_Sinatra_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Duets (Frank Sinatra album) (page does not exist)">Duets</a></i>, which was released in November.
</p><p>The other artists who added their vocals to the album worked for free, and a follow-up album (<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Duets_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Duets II (page does not exist)">Duets II</a></i>) was released in 1994 that reached No.9 on the <i>Billboard</i> charts.
</p><p>Still touring despite various health problems, Sinatra remained a top concert attraction on a global scale during the first half of the 1990s. At times during concerts his memory failed him and a fall onstage in <a href="/wiki/Richmond,_Virginia" title="Richmond, Virginia">Richmond, Virginia</a>, in March 1994, signaled further problems.
</p><p>Sinatra's final public concerts were held in Japan's <a href="/wiki/Fukuoka_Dome" title="Fukuoka Dome">Fukuoka Dome</a> in December 1994. The following year, on February 25, 1995, at a private party for 1200 select guests on the closing night of the Frank Sinatra Desert Classic golf tournament, Sinatra sang before a live audience for the very last time. <i><a href="/wiki/Esquire_(magazine)" title="Esquire (magazine)">Esquire</a></i> reported of the show that Sinatra was "clear, tough, on the money" and "in absolute control". His closing song was "<a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Best_Is_Yet_to_Come_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Best Is Yet to Come (song) (page does not exist)">The Best is Yet to Come</a>".
</p><p>Sinatra was awarded the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Legend_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grammy Legend Award (page does not exist)">Legend Award</a> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=1994_Grammy_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1994 Grammy Awards (page does not exist)">1994 Grammy Awards</a>, where he was introduced by <a href="/wiki/Bono" title="Bono">Bono</a>, who said of him, "Frank's the chairman of the bad attitude&#160;... Rock 'n roll plays at being tough, but this guy is the boss—the chairman of boss&#160;... I'm not going to mess with him, are you?"<sup id="cite_ref-bono_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bono-43">[43]</a></sup> Sinatra called it "the best welcome&#160;... I ever had", but his acceptance speech ran too long and was abruptly cut off, leaving him looking confused and talking into a dead microphone.<sup id="cite_ref-Bono_at_Grammys_1994_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bono_at_Grammys_1994-44">[44]</a></sup> Later in the telecast, <a href="/wiki/Billy_Joel" title="Billy Joel">Billy Joel</a> protested the decision to cut Sinatra off by leaving a long pause in the middle of his song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=The_River_of_Dreams&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The River of Dreams (page does not exist)">The River of Dreams</a>" in order to waste "valuable advertising time".<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1995, to mark Sinatra's 80th birthday, the <a href="/wiki/Empire_State_Building" title="Empire State Building">Empire State Building</a> glowed blue. A star-studded birthday tribute, <i>Sinatra: 80 Years My Way</i>, was held at the <a href="/wiki/Shrine_Auditorium" title="Shrine Auditorium">Shrine Auditorium</a> in Los Angeles. At the end of the program Sinatra graced the stage for the last time to sing the final notes of "<a href="/wiki/Theme_from_New_York,_New_York" title="Theme from New York, New York">New York, New York</a>" with an ensemble. It was Sinatra's last televised appearance.
</p><p>In recognition of his many years of association with Las Vegas, Frank Sinatra was elected to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gaming_Hall_of_Fame&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gaming Hall of Fame (page does not exist)">Gaming Hall of Fame</a> in 1997.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Film_career">Film career</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Sinatra enjoyed a highly successful film career and began making movies almost as soon as his singing career took off. His most important <a href="/wiki/Motion_pictures" title="Motion pictures" class="mw-redirect">pictures</a>, among many others spanning most of his lengthy career, include:
</p>
<ul>
<li>  <i><a href="/wiki/The_Manchurian_Candidate_(1962_film)" title="The Manchurian Candidate (1962 film)">The Manchurian Candidate</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Angela_Lansbury" title="Angela Lansbury">Angela Lansbury</a>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/wiki/From_Here_to_Eternity" title="From Here to Eternity">From Here to Eternity</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Burt_Lancaster" title="Burt Lancaster">Burt Lancaster</a>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/wiki/Suddenly_(1954_film)" title="Suddenly (1954 film)">Suddenly</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Sterling_Hayden" title="Sterling Hayden">Sterling Hayden</a>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/wiki/The_Man_with_the_Golden_Arm" title="The Man with the Golden Arm">The Man with the Golden Arm</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Arnold_Stang" title="Arnold Stang">Arnold Stang</a>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kings_Go_Forth&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kings Go Forth (page does not exist)">Kings Go Forth</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Natalie_Wood" title="Natalie Wood">Natalie Wood</a>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Guys_and_Dolls_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Guys and Dolls (film) (page does not exist)">Guys and Dolls</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Marlon_Brando" title="Marlon Brando">Marlon Brando</a>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/wiki/High_Society_(1956_film)" title="High Society (1956 film)">High Society</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Bing_Crosby" title="Bing Crosby">Bing Crosby</a>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Pal_Joey_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pal Joey (film) (page does not exist)">Pal Joey</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Rita_Hayworth" title="Rita Hayworth">Rita Hayworth</a>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Some_Came_Running&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Some Came Running (page does not exist)">Some Came Running</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Dean_Martin" title="Dean Martin">Dean Martin</a>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Never_So_Few&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Never So Few (page does not exist)">Never So Few</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Steve_McQueen" title="Steve McQueen">Steve McQueen</a>
</li>
