<li>  <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Hole_in_the_Head&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Hole in the Head (page does not exist)">A Hole in the Head</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Edward_G._Robinson" title="Edward G. Robinson">Edward G. Robinson</a>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Meet_Danny_Wilson_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Meet Danny Wilson (film) (page does not exist)">Meet Danny Wilson</a></i>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=On_the_Town_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="On the Town (film) (page does not exist)">On the Town</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Gene_Kelly" title="Gene Kelly">Gene Kelly</a>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/wiki/Robin_and_the_7_Hoods" title="Robin and the 7 Hoods">Robin and the 7 Hoods</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Bing_Crosby" title="Bing Crosby">Bing Crosby</a>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ocean%27s_11_(1960_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ocean's 11 (1960 film) (page does not exist)">Ocean's 11</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sergeants_3&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sergeants 3 (page does not exist)">Sergeants 3</a></i> with the <a href="/wiki/Rat_Pack" title="Rat Pack">Rat Pack</a> (<a href="/wiki/Dean_Martin" title="Dean Martin">Dean Martin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sammy_Davis,_Jr." title="Sammy Davis, Jr.">Sammy Davis, Jr.</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Lawford" title="Peter Lawford">Peter Lawford</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Joey_Bishop" title="Joey Bishop">Joey Bishop</a>)
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/wiki/Von_Ryan%27s_Express" title="Von Ryan's Express">Von Ryan's Express</a></i>, with <a href="/wiki/Trevor_Howard" title="Trevor Howard">Trevor Howard</a>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Step_Lively_(1944_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Step Lively (1944 film) (page does not exist)">Step Lively</a></i>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=None_But_the_Brave&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="None But the Brave (page does not exist)">None But the Brave</a></i> (directed by Sinatra)
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Naked_Runner_(1967_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Naked Runner (1967 film) (page does not exist)">The Naked Runner (1967 film)</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Peter_Vaughan" title="Peter Vaughan">Peter Vaughan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Edward_Fox" title="Edward Fox">Edward Fox</a>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Detective_(1968_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Detective (1968 film) (page does not exist)">The Detective</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Lee_Remick" title="Lee Remick">Lee Remick</a>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/wiki/Come_Blow_Your_Horn" title="Come Blow Your Horn">Come Blow Your Horn</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Lee_J._Cobb" title="Lee J. Cobb">Lee J. Cobb</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Barbara_Rush&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Barbara Rush (page does not exist)">Barbara Rush</a>
</li>
<li>  <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Pride_and_the_Passion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Pride and the Passion (page does not exist)">The Pride and the Passion</a></i> starring <a href="/wiki/Cary_Grant" title="Cary Grant">Cary Grant</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_life">Personal life</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Sinatra had three children, <a href="/wiki/Nancy_Sinatra" title="Nancy Sinatra">Nancy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frank_Sinatra,_Jr." title="Frank Sinatra, Jr.">Frank Jr.</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tina_Sinatra" title="Tina Sinatra">Tina</a>, all with his first wife, Nancy Sinatra (née Barbato) (m. 1939–1951). He was married three more times, to actresses <a href="/wiki/Ava_Gardner" title="Ava Gardner">Ava Gardner</a> (m. 1951–1957), <a href="/wiki/Mia_Farrow" title="Mia Farrow">Mia Farrow</a> (m. 1966–1968), and finally to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Barbara_Marx&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Barbara Marx (page does not exist)">Barbara Marx</a> (m. 1976–1998; his death).
</p><p>Throughout his life, Sinatra had mood swings and bouts of <a href="/wiki/Depression_(mood)" title="Depression (mood)">depression</a>. Avoiding solitude and unglamorous surroundings at all cost, he struggled with the conflicting need "to get away from it all, but not too far away."<sup id="cite_ref-Kaplan_28-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kaplan-28">[28]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> He acknowledged this, telling an interviewer in the 1950s: "Being an 18-karat <a href="/wiki/Manic_depressive" title="Manic depressive" class="mw-redirect">manic depressive</a>, and having lived a life of violent emotional contradictions, I have an over-acute capacity for sadness as well as elation."<sup id="cite_ref-Summers_Swan_2-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Summers_Swan-2">[2]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> In her memoirs <i>My Father's Daughter</i>, his daughter Tina wrote about the "eighteen-karat" remark: "As flippant as Dad could be about his mental state, I believe that a <a href="/wiki/Zoloft" title="Zoloft" class="mw-redirect">Zoloft</a> a day might have kept his demons away. But that kind of medicine was decades off."<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although beloved as a hero by his hometown of Hoboken, Frank Sinatra rarely visited it. According to one account, Sinatra returned once in 1948 to celebrate the election of Hoboken's first Italian mayor and was not well received by the crowd. He stated he would never come back, and in fact did not return until 1984, to appear with <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Alleged_organized-crime_links">Alleged organized-crime links</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Sinatra's alleged personal and professional links with <a href="/wiki/Organized_crime" title="Organized crime">organized-crime</a><sup id="cite_ref-FBI_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FBI-49">[49]</a></sup> figures such as <a href="/wiki/Carlo_Gambino" title="Carlo Gambino">Carlo Gambino</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-mafia_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mafia-50">[50]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sam_Giancana&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sam Giancana (page does not exist)">Sam Giancana</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-mafia_50-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mafia-50">[50]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lucky_Luciano" title="Lucky Luciano">Lucky Luciano</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-mafia_50-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mafia-50">[50]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Joseph_Fischetti&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Joseph Fischetti (page does not exist)">Joseph Fischetti</a> garnered considerable attention.<sup id="cite_ref-mafia_50-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mafia-50">[50]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation" title="Federal Bureau of Investigation">Federal Bureau of Investigation</a> kept records amounting to 2,403 pages on Sinatra. With his alleged <a href="/wiki/Mafia" title="Mafia">Mafia</a> ties, his ardent <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Deal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Deal (page does not exist)">New Deal</a> politics and his friendship with <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_F._Kennedy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John F. Kennedy (page does not exist)">John F. Kennedy</a>, he was a natural target for <a href="/wiki/J._Edgar_Hoover" title="J. Edgar Hoover">J. Edgar Hoover</a>'s FBI.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> The FBI kept Sinatra under surveillance for almost five decades beginning in the 1940s. The documents include accounts of Sinatra as the target of death threats and <a href="/wiki/Extortion" title="Extortion">extortion</a> schemes. They also portray rampant <a href="/wiki/Paranoia" title="Paranoia">paranoia</a> and strange obsessions at the FBI and reveal nearly every celebrated Sinatra foible and peccadillo.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>For a year Hoover investigated Sinatra's alleged Communist affiliations, but found no evidence. The files include his rendezvous with prostitutes, and his extramarital affair with Ava Gardner, which preceded their marriage. Celebrities mentioned in the files are <a href="/wiki/Dean_Martin" title="Dean Martin">Dean Martin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marilyn_Monroe" title="Marilyn Monroe">Marilyn Monroe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Lawford" title="Peter Lawford">Peter Lawford</a>, and Giancana's girlfriend, singer <a href="/wiki/Phyllis_McGuire" title="Phyllis McGuire" class="mw-redirect">Phyllis McGuire</a>.
</p><p>The FBI's secret dossier on Sinatra was released in 1998 in response to <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_Information_Act_(United_States)" title="Freedom of Information Act (United States)">Freedom of Information Act</a> requests.
</p><p>The released FBI files reveal some tantalizing insights into Sinatra's lifetime consistency in pursuing and embracing seemingly conflicting affiliations. But Sinatra's alliances had a practical aspect. They were adaptive mechanisms for behavior motivated by self-interest and inner anxieties. In September 1950 Sinatra felt particularly vulnerable. He was in a panic over his moribund career and haunted by the continual speculations and innuendos in circulation regarding his draft status in World War II. Sinatra "was scared, his career had sprung a leak." In a letter dated September 17, 1950, to <a href="/wiki/Clyde_Tolson" title="Clyde Tolson">Clyde Tolson</a>, Deputy FBI Director, Sinatra offered to be of service to the FBI as an informer. An excerpted passage from a memo in FBI files states that Sinatra "feels he can be of help as a result of going anywhere the Bureau desires and contacting any people from whom he might be able to obtain information. Sinatra feels as a result of his publicity he can operate without suspicion&#160;... he is willing to go the whole way." The FBI declined his assistance.<sup id="cite_ref-Kaplan_28-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kaplan-28">[28]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_views">Political views</span></h2>
<p>Sinatra held differing political views throughout his life.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Eleanor_Roosevelt_Frank_Sinatra_1947.jpg" title="File:Eleanor Roosevelt Frank Sinatra 1947.jpg">File:Eleanor Roosevelt Frank Sinatra 1947.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Eleanor_Roosevelt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eleanor Roosevelt (page does not exist)">Eleanor Roosevelt</a> and Sinatra in 1947; Sinatra named his son after her husband.</div></div></div>
<p>Sinatra's parents had immigrated to the United States in 1895 and 1897 respectively. His mother, Dolly Sinatra (1896–1977), was a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Democratic_Party_(U.S.)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Democratic Party (U.S.) (page does not exist)">Democratic Party</a> ward leader.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sinatra remained a supporter of the Democratic Party until the early 1970s when he switched his allegiance to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Republican_Party_(U.S.)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Republican Party (U.S.) (page does not exist)">Republican Party</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_activities_1944.E2.80.9368">Political activities 1944–68</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Eleanor_Roosevelt_Frank_Sinatra.jpg" title="File:Eleanor Roosevelt Frank Sinatra.jpg">File:Eleanor Roosevelt Frank Sinatra.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sinatra, pictured here with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eleanor_Roosevelt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eleanor Roosevelt (page does not exist)">Eleanor Roosevelt</a> in 1960, was an ardent supporter of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Democratic_Party_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Democratic Party (United States) (page does not exist)">Democratic Party</a> until 1970.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1944, after sending a letter to President <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a>, Sinatra was invited to meet Roosevelt at the <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">White House</a>, where he agreed to become part of the Democratic party's voter registration drives.<sup id="cite_ref-MartinSmith_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MartinSmith-54">[54]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>He donated $5,000 to the Democrats for the <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1944" title="United States presidential election, 1944">1944 presidential election</a> and by the end of the campaign was appearing at two or three political events every day.<sup id="cite_ref-MartinSmith_54-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MartinSmith-54">[54]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>After World War II, Sinatra's politics grew steadily more left wing,<sup id="cite_ref-MartinSmith_54-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MartinSmith-54">[54]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> and he became more publicly associated with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Popular_Front&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Popular Front (page does not exist)">Popular Front</a>. He started reading progressive literature and supported many organizations that were later identified as <a href="/wiki/Front_organizations" title="Front organizations" class="mw-redirect">front organizations</a> of the Communist Party by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=House_Un-American_Activities_Committee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="House Un-American Activities Committee (page does not exist)">House Un-American Activities Committee</a> in the 1950s, though Sinatra was never brought before the committee.
</p><p>Sinatra spoke at a number of New Jersey high schools in 1945, where students had gone on strike in opposition to <a href="/wiki/Racial_integration" title="Racial integration">racial integration</a>. Later that year Sinatra would appear in <i><a href="/wiki/The_House_I_Live_In_(1945_film)" title="The House I Live In (1945 film)">The House I Live In</a></i>, a short film that stood against <a href="/wiki/Racism" title="Racism">racism</a>. The film was scripted by <a href="/wiki/Albert_Maltz" title="Albert Maltz">Albert Maltz</a>, with the title song written by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Earl_Robinson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Earl Robinson (page does not exist)">Earl Robinson</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abel_Meeropol" title="Abel Meeropol">Abel Meeropol</a> (under the pseudonym of Lewis Allen).
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1948" title="United States presidential election, 1948">1948</a>, Sinatra actively campaigned for President <a href="/w/index.php?title=Harry_S._Truman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Harry S. Truman (page does not exist)">Harry S. Truman</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup> In 1952 and 1956, he also campaigned for <a href="/wiki/Adlai_Stevenson_II" title="Adlai Stevenson II">Adlai Stevenson</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup> In 1956 and 1960, Sinatra sang the <a href="/wiki/The_Star-Spangled_Banner" title="The Star-Spangled Banner">National Anthem</a> at the Democratic National Convention.<sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>Of all the U.S. Presidents he associated with during his career, he was closest to <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_F._Kennedy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John F. Kennedy (page does not exist)">John F. Kennedy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup> In 1960, Sinatra and his friends Peter Lawford, Dean Martin, and Sammy Davis Jr. actively campaigned for Kennedy throughout the United States;<sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup> On the campaign trail, Sinatra's voice was heard even if he was not physically present.<sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup> The campaign's theme song, played before every appearance, was a newly recorded version of "High Hopes," specially recorded by Sinatra with new lyrics saluting JFK.<sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>In January 1961, Sinatra and <a href="/wiki/Peter_Lawford" title="Peter Lawford">Peter Lawford</a> organized the Inaugural Gala in Washington, DC, held on the evening before President Kennedy was sworn into office.<sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup> The event, featuring many big show business stars, was an enormous success, raising a large amount of money for the Democratic Party. Sinatra also organized an Inaugural Gala in California in 1962 to welcome second term Democratic <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_California" title="Governor of California">Governor</a> <a href="/wiki/Pat_Brown" title="Pat Brown">Pat Brown</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kelley_5-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kelley-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>Sinatra's move toward the Republicans seems to have begun when he was snubbed by President Kennedy in favor of <a href="/wiki/Bing_Crosby" title="Bing Crosby">Bing Crosby</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-lpo_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lpo-56">[56]</a></sup> a rival singer and a Republican, for Kennedy's visit to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Palm_Springs,_California&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Palm Springs, California (page does not exist)">Palm Springs</a>, in 1962. Kennedy had planned to stay at Sinatra's home over the Easter holiday weekend, but decided against doing so because of Sinatra's alleged connections to organized crime.<sup id="cite_ref-lpo_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lpo-56">[56]</a></sup> Kennedy stayed at Crosby's house instead.<sup id="cite_ref-lpo_56-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lpo-56">[56]</a></sup> Sinatra had invested a lot of his own money in upgrading the facilities at his home in anticipation of the President's visit.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> At the time, President Kennedy's brother, Attorney General <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_F._Kennedy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robert F. Kennedy (page does not exist)">Robert F. Kennedy</a>, was intensifying his own investigations into organized crime figures such as Chicago mob boss <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sam_Giancana&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sam Giancana (page does not exist)">Sam Giancana</a>, who had earlier stayed at Sinatra's home.
</p><p>Despite his break with Kennedy, however, he still mourned over Kennedy after he learned he was assassinated.<sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup> According to his daughter Nancy, he learned of Kennedy's assassination while filming a scene of <i><a href="/wiki/Robin_and_the_7_Hoods" title="Robin and the 7 Hoods">Robin and the 7 Hoods</a></i> in Burbank.<sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup> After he learned of the assassination, Sinatra quickly finished filming the scene, returned to his Palm Springs home, and sobbed in his bedroom for three days.<sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1968" title="United States presidential election, 1968">1968 election</a> illustrated changes in the once solidly pro-JFK Rat Pack: <a href="/wiki/Peter_Lawford" title="Peter Lawford">Peter Lawford</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sammy_Davis,_Jr." title="Sammy Davis, Jr.">Sammy Davis, Jr.</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Shirley_MacLaine" title="Shirley MacLaine">Shirley MacLaine</a> all endorsed Robert Kennedy in the spring primaries; Sinatra, <a href="/wiki/Dean_Martin" title="Dean Martin">Dean Martin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Joey_Bishop" title="Joey Bishop">Joey Bishop</a> backed Vice-President <a href="/wiki/Hubert_Humphrey" title="Hubert Humphrey">Hubert Humphrey</a>. In the fall election, Sinatra appeared for Humphrey in Texas at the <a href="/wiki/Houston_Astrodome" title="Houston Astrodome" class="mw-redirect">Houston Astrodome</a> with President <a href="/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson" title="Lyndon B. Johnson">Lyndon B. Johnson</a> and in a television commercial soliciting campaign contributions.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> He also re-stated his support for Humphrey on a live election-eve national telethon.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_activities_1970.E2.80.9394">Political activities 1970–94</span></h3>
<p>In 1970, the first sign of Sinatra's break from the Democratic Party came when he endorsed <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> for a second term as <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_California" title="Governor of California">Governor of California</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-MichaelFreedland_42-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MichaelFreedland-42">[42]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup> Sinatra, however, remained a registered Democrat and encouraged Reagan to become more moderate.<sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup> In July 1972, after a lifetime of supporting Democratic presidential candidates, Sinatra announced he would support Republican U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">Richard Nixon</a> for re-election in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1972" title="United States presidential election, 1972">1972 presidential election</a>. His switch to the Republican Party was now official;<sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup> he even told his daughter Tina, who had actively campaigned for Nixon's Democratic opponent <a href="/wiki/George_McGovern" title="George McGovern">George McGovern</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup> "the older you get, the more conservative you get."<sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup> Sinatra said he agreed with the Republican Party on most positions, except that of abortion.<sup id="cite_ref-MartinSmith_54-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MartinSmith-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Frank_Sinatra_and_Ronald_Reagan.jpg" title="File:Frank Sinatra and Ronald Reagan.jpg">File:Frank Sinatra and Ronald Reagan.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sinatra is awarded the <a href="/wiki/Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom" title="Presidential Medal of Freedom">Presidential Medal of Freedom</a> by President <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>During Nixon's Presidency, Sinatra visited the White House on several occasions.<sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup> Sinatra also became a good friend of Vice President <a href="/wiki/Spiro_Agnew" title="Spiro Agnew">Spiro Agnew</a>. In 1973, Agnew was charged with corruption and resigned as Vice President; Sinatra helped Agnew pay some of his legal bills.<sup id="cite_ref-Kelley_5-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kelley-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1980" title="United States presidential election, 1980">1980 presidential election</a>, Sinatra supported Ronald Reagan, and donated $4&#160;million to Reagan's campaign. Sinatra said he supported Reagan as he was "the proper man to be the President of the United States&#160;... it's so screwed up now, we need someone to straighten it out."<sup id="cite_ref-MichaelFreedland_42-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MichaelFreedland-42">[42]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> Reagan's victory gave Sinatra his closest relationship with the White House since the early 1960s.<sup id="cite_ref-ws.3B_55-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ws.3B-55">[55]</a></sup> Sinatra arranged Reagan's Presidential gala,<sup id="cite_ref-Kelley_5-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kelley-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> as he had done for Kennedy 20 years previously.
</p><p>In 1984, Sinatra returned to his birthplace in Hoboken, bringing with him President Reagan, who was in the midst of campaigning for the <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1984" title="United States presidential election, 1984">1984 presidential election</a>. Reagan had made Sinatra a fund-raising ambassador as part of the Republican National Committee's "Victory '84 Get-Out-The-Vote" (GOTV) drive.<sup id="cite_ref-Kelley_5-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kelley-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a><sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> On January 19, 1985, Sinatra hosted the 50th Presidential Inaugural Gala, the day before the second inauguration of <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a>.
</p><p>On January 19, 1989, Sinatra performed "You'll Never Walk Alone" at President George H.W. Bush's inaugural gala.
</p><p>Although Sinatra never performed for President Bill Clinton the two did meet and go out to dinner on occasion. Clinton said of Sinatra: "I had the opportunity after I became president to get to know him a little, to have dinner with him, to appreciate on a personal level what fans around the world, including me, appreciated from afar."
</p><p>Posthumously on August 30, 2004 at the Republican National Convention, incumbent President George W. Bush and Mayor Rudy Giuliani of New York City asked for permission to play a video from the White House archives of Sinatra performing "New York, New York." The Sinatra estate granted permission and a video recording of Sinatra from the 1981 inaugural gala (which he produced) was shown on the projection screens in the auditorium and later that evening on television.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Death">Death</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sinatra.jpg" title="File:Sinatra.jpg">File:Sinatra.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sinatra's gravestone</div></div></div>
<p>Sinatra began showing signs of dementia in his last years. In 1996 he made the fewest public appearances he had ever made in his entire life up until that point. In February 1996 he came on stage briefly at the Sinatra Celebrity Invitational golf tournament in Palm Springs, California and intended to sing the final bars of "New York, New York" but the band cut off abruptly before he could grab a microphone. His final public appearance was on July 22, 1996 at a televised <a href="/wiki/Three_Tenors" title="Three Tenors" class="mw-redirect">Three Tenors</a> performance at Giants stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey. He sat in the first row of the audience and was shown on camera during "My Way" nodding in approval and smiling, finally at the end of the song he stood up in front of the crowd of 40,000 people and said "Bravo!" as the Three Tenors waved back at him.  Following a heart attack in February 1997, he made no further public appearances. He had a second heart attack on May 14 of the following year,<sup id="cite_ref-holden_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-holden-60">[60]</a></sup> and died at the <a href="/wiki/Cedars-Sinai_Medical_Center" title="Cedars-Sinai Medical Center">Cedars-Sinai Medical Center</a>, with his wife, Barbara, by his side.<sup id="cite_ref-holden_60-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-holden-60">[60]</a></sup> He was 82 years old.<sup id="cite_ref-holden_60-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-holden-60">[60]</a></sup> After Barbara encouraged him to "fight" while attempts were made to stabilize him, Sinatra's final words were, "I'm losing."<sup id="cite_ref-farewell_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-farewell-61">[61]</a></sup> The official cause of death was listed as complications from dementia, heart and kidney disease, and bladder cancer.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> His death was confirmed by the Sinatra family on their website with a statement accompanied by a recording of the singer's version of "Softly As I Leave You". The next night, the lights on the <a href="/wiki/Las_Vegas_Strip" title="Las Vegas Strip">Las Vegas Strip</a> were dimmed for 10 minutes in his honor and the lights on the <a href="/wiki/Empire_State_Building" title="Empire State Building">Empire State Building</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York (page does not exist)">New York</a> were turned blue. President <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a>, an amateur saxophonist and musician, said that after meeting and getting to know the singer, he had "come to appreciate on a personal level what millions of people had appreciated from afar".<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_.E2.80.93_Clinton_leads_Sinatra_tributes_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_.E2.80.93_Clinton_leads_Sinatra_tributes-63">[63]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elton_John&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elton John (page does not exist)">Elton John</a> stated that Sinatra "was simply the best – no one else even comes close".<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_.E2.80.93_Clinton_leads_Sinatra_tributes_63-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_.E2.80.93_Clinton_leads_Sinatra_tributes-63">[63]</a></sup>
</p><p>On May 20, 1998, at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_Catholic_Church_of_the_Good_Shepherd_(Beverly_Hills)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roman Catholic Church of the Good Shepherd (Beverly Hills) (page does not exist)">Roman Catholic Church of the Good Shepherd</a> in <a href="/wiki/Beverly_Hills,_California" title="Beverly Hills, California">Beverly Hills, California</a>, Sinatra's funeral was held, with 400 mourners in attendance and hundreds of fans outside.<sup id="cite_ref-finalcurtain_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-finalcurtain-64">[64]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gregory_Peck" title="Gregory Peck">Gregory Peck</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tony_Bennett" title="Tony Bennett">Tony Bennett</a>, and Frank, Jr., addressed the mourners, among whom were <a href="/wiki/Jill_St._John" title="Jill St. John">Jill St. John</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Selleck" title="Tom Selleck">Tom Selleck</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joey_Bishop" title="Joey Bishop">Joey Bishop</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jack_Wagner_(actor)" title="Jack Wagner (actor)">Jack Wagner</a>, <a href="/wiki/Faye_Dunaway" title="Faye Dunaway">Faye Dunaway</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tony_Curtis" title="Tony Curtis">Tony Curtis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liza_Minnelli" title="Liza Minnelli">Liza Minnelli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kirk_Douglas" title="Kirk Douglas">Kirk Douglas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Wagner" title="Robert Wagner">Robert Wagner</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bob_Dylan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bob Dylan (page does not exist)">Bob Dylan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Don_Rickles" title="Don Rickles">Don Rickles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nancy_Reagan" title="Nancy Reagan">Nancy Reagan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Angie_Dickinson" title="Angie Dickinson">Angie Dickinson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sophia_Loren" title="Sophia Loren">Sophia Loren</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bob_Newhart" title="Bob Newhart">Bob Newhart</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mia_Farrow" title="Mia Farrow">Mia Farrow</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jack_Nicholson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jack Nicholson (page does not exist)">Jack Nicholson</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-farewell_61-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-farewell-61">[61]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-finalcurtain_64-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-finalcurtain-64">[64]</a></sup> A private ceremony was held later that day at St. Theresa's Catholic Church in Palm Springs. Sinatra was buried next to his parents in section B-8 of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Desert_Memorial_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Desert Memorial Park (page does not exist)">Desert Memorial Park</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cathedral_City,_California" title="Cathedral City, California">Cathedral City, California</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-PSCemDis_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PSCemDis-1">[1]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-farewell_61-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-farewell-61">[61]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> His close friends, <a href="/wiki/Jilly_Rizzo" title="Jilly Rizzo">Jilly Rizzo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Van_Heusen" title="Jimmy Van Heusen">Jimmy Van Heusen</a>, are buried nearby. The words "The Best Is Yet to Come" are imprinted on Sinatra's grave marker.<sup id="cite_ref-Wayne2006_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wayne2006-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Frank_Sinatra_Hollywood_star.jpg" title="File:Frank Sinatra Hollywood star.jpg">File:Frank Sinatra Hollywood star.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Frank Sinatra's star on the <a href="/wiki/Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame" title="Hollywood Walk of Fame">Hollywood Walk of Fame</a>, located on 1637 Vine Street</div></div></div>
<div class="quotebox" style="float: right; clear: right; margin: 0.5em 0 0.8em 1.4em; width: 35%; padding: 6px; border: 1px solid #aaa; font-size: 88%; background-color: #F9F9F9;">
<div style="position: relative; text-align: left;">
<div>
<p>"Sinatra was&#160;... the first modern pop superstar&#160;... Following his idol <a href="/wiki/Bing_Crosby" title="Bing Crosby">Bing Crosby</a>, who had pioneered the use of the <a href="/wiki/Microphone" title="Microphone">microphone</a>, Sinatra transformed popular singing by infusing lyrics with a personal, intimate point of view that conveyed a steady current of eroticism&#160;... Almost singlehandedly, he helped lead a revival of vocalized swing music that took American pop to a new level of musical sophistication&#160;... his 1950s recordings&#160;... were instrumental in establishing a canon of American pop song literature."
</p>
</div>
</div>
<div style="text-align: left;">--<a href="/w/index.php?title=Stephen_Holden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stephen Holden (page does not exist)">Stephen Holden</a><sup id="cite_ref-holden_60-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-holden-60">[60]</a></sup></div>
</div>
<p>Philadelphia radio DJ <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sid_Mark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sid Mark (page does not exist)">Sid Mark</a> has hosted a Frank Sinatra show (Friday with Frank, Saturday with Sinatra, Sunday with Sinatra) for over 50 years.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Importance-inline&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Importance-inline (page does not exist)">Template:Importance-inline</a>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/United_States_Postal_Service" title="United States Postal Service">U.S. Postal Service</a> issued a 42-cent postage stamp in honor of Sinatra on May 13, 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-sinatraasidol_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sinatraasidol-67">[67]</a></sup> The design of the stamp was unveiled Wednesday, December 12, 2007 – on what would have been his 92nd birthday – in <a href="/wiki/Beverly_Hills,_California" title="Beverly Hills, California">Beverly Hills</a>, California, with Sinatra family members on hand.<sup id="cite_ref-stamp_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stamp-68">[68]</a></sup> The design shows a 1950s-vintage image of Sinatra, wearing a hat. The design also includes his signature, with his last name alone.<sup id="cite_ref-stamp_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stamp-68">[68]</a></sup> The Hoboken Post Office was renamed in his honor in 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-stamp_68-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stamp-68">[68]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frank_Sinatra_School_of_the_Arts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frank Sinatra School of the Arts (page does not exist)">Frank Sinatra School of the Arts</a> in <a href="/wiki/Astoria,_Queens" title="Astoria, Queens">Astoria, Queens</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Frank_Sinatra_Park" title="Frank Sinatra Park" class="mw-redirect">Frank Sinatra Park</a> in Hoboken were named in his honor.
</p><p>The U.S. Congress passed a resolution on May 20, 2008, designating May 13 as Frank Sinatra Day to honor his contribution to American culture. The resolution was introduced by <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_House_of_Representatives&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States House of Representatives (page does not exist)">Representative</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mary_Bono_Mack&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mary Bono Mack (page does not exist)">Mary Bono Mack</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-march13_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-march13-69">[69]</a></sup>
</p><p>To commemorate the anniversary of Sinatra's death, Patsy's Restaurant in New York City, which Sinatra frequented, exhibited in May 2009 fifteen previously unseen photographs of Sinatra taken by Bobby Bank.<sup id="cite_ref-stamper_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stamper-70">[70]</a></sup> The photos are of his recording "Everybody Ought to Be in Love" at a nearby recording studio.<sup id="cite_ref-stamper_70-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stamper-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stephen Holden wrote for the 1983 <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rolling_Stone_Record_Guide&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rolling Stone Record Guide (page does not exist)">Rolling Stone Record Guide</a></i>:
</p>
<dl>
<dd> Frank Sinatra's voice <i>is</i> pop music history.&#160;... Like <a href="/wiki/Elvis_Presley" title="Elvis Presley">Presley</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bob_Dylan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bob Dylan (page does not exist)">Dylan</a> – the only other white male American singers since 1940 whose popularity, influence, and mythic force have been comparable – Sinatra will last indefinitely. He virtually invented modern pop song phrasing.
</dd>
</dl>
<p><a href="/wiki/Wynn_Resorts" title="Wynn Resorts">Wynn Resorts</a> dedicated a signature restaurant to Sinatra inside <a href="/w/index.php?title=Encore_Las_Vegas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Encore Las Vegas (page does not exist)">Encore Las Vegas</a> on December 22, 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-Opening_of_Sinatra_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Opening_of_Sinatra-71">[71]</a></sup> Memorabilia in the restaurant includes his Oscar for "<a href="/wiki/From_Here_to_Eternity" title="From Here to Eternity">From Here to Eternity</a>", his Emmy for "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Frank_Sinatra:_A_Man_and_His_Music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frank Sinatra: A Man and His Music (page does not exist)">Frank Sinatra: A Man and His Music</a>", his Grammy for "<a href="/wiki/Strangers_in_the_Night" title="Strangers in the Night">Strangers in the Night</a>", photographs and a gold album he received for "Classic Sinatra".
</p><p>There is a residence hall at <a href="/wiki/Montclair_State_University" title="Montclair State University">Montclair State University</a> named for him in recognition of his status as an iconic New Jersey native.<sup id="cite_ref-MSU_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MSU-72">[72]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Frank Sinatra International Student Center at Israel's Hebrew University, Mt. Scopus campus, Jerusalem, was dedicated in 1978 in recognition of Sinatra's charitable and advocacy activities on behalf of the State of Israel.
</p><p>In 1999, <a href="/wiki/Huell_Howser" title="Huell Howser">Huell Howser</a> Productions, in association with <a href="/wiki/KCET" title="KCET">KCET</a>/Los Angeles, featured Frank Sinatra's Palm Springs home in <i><a href="/wiki/California%27s_Gold" title="California's Gold">California's Gold</a></i>; the 49 minute program is available on VHS.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Film_and_television_portrayals">Film and television portrayals</span></h3>
<ul>
<li> In <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Godfather&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Godfather (page does not exist)">The Godfather</a></i>, fictional singer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Johnny_Fontane&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Johnny Fontane (page does not exist)">Johnny Fontane</a>, whose career was helped by organized crime boss <a href="/wiki/Vito_Corleone" title="Vito Corleone">Vito Corleone</a>, was recognized by many, even Sinatra, as being based on his life.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> In 1992, CBS aired a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sinatra_(TV_miniseries)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sinatra (TV miniseries) (page does not exist)">TV mini-series</a> about the entertainer's life titled, <i>Sinatra</i>, directed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Steven_Sadwith&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James Steven Sadwith (page does not exist)">James Steven Sadwith</a> and starred <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philip_Casnoff&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philip Casnoff (page does not exist)">Philip Casnoff</a> as Sinatra. Opening with his childhood in Hoboken, New Jersey, the film follows Sinatra's rise to the top in the 1940s, through the dark days of the early 1950s and his triumphant re-emergence in the mid-1950s, to his status as pop culture icon in the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s. In between, the film hits all of the main events, including his three marriages, his connections with the Mafia and his notorious friendship with the Rat Pack. <a href="/wiki/Tina_Sinatra" title="Tina Sinatra">Tina Sinatra</a> was executive producer. Casnoff received a <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe" title="Golden Globe" class="mw-redirect">Golden Globe</a> nomination for his performance.
</li>
<li> In 1998, <a href="/wiki/Ray_Liotta" title="Ray Liotta">Ray Liotta</a> portrayed Sinatra in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=HBO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="HBO (page does not exist)">HBO</a> movie <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Rat_Pack_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Rat Pack (film) (page does not exist)">The Rat Pack</a></i>, alongside <a href="/wiki/Joe_Mantegna" title="Joe Mantegna">Joe Mantegna</a> as <a href="/wiki/Dean_Martin" title="Dean Martin">Dean Martin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Don_Cheadle" title="Don Cheadle">Don Cheadle</a> as <a href="/wiki/Sammy_Davis,_Jr." title="Sammy Davis, Jr.">Sammy Davis, Jr.</a>. It depicted their contribution to <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_F._Kennedy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John F. Kennedy (page does not exist)">John F. Kennedy</a>'s election as U.S. president in 1960.
</li>
<li> Episode 4 of the Areana Series was issued in 1998 and dedicated to the life and work of Frank Sinatra, entitled "The Voice of a Century"
</li>
<li> Joe Piscopo and the late <a href="/wiki/Phil_Hartman" title="Phil Hartman">Phil Hartman</a> spoofed Sinatra on <i><a href="/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live" title="Saturday Night Live">Saturday Night Live</a></i>.
</li>
<li> In 2003, Sinatra was portrayed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Russo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James Russo (page does not exist)">James Russo</a> in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Stealing_Sinatra&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stealing Sinatra (page does not exist)">Stealing Sinatra</a></i>, which revolved around the kidnapping of Frank Sinatra Jr. in 1963.
</li>
<li> Also in 2003, he was portrayed by <a href="/wiki/Dennis_Hopper" title="Dennis Hopper">Dennis Hopper</a> in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Night_We_Called_It_a_Day_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Night We Called It a Day (film) (page does not exist)">The Night We Called It a Day</a></i>, based upon events that occurred during a tour of Australia where Frank had called a member of the news media a "two-bit hooker" and all the unions in the country came crashing down on him.
</li>
<li> Sinatra was also portrayed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sebastian_Anzaldo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sebastian Anzaldo (page does not exist)">Sebastian Anzaldo</a> in the film <i>Tears of a King</i>, who also impersonated Sinatra in a TV episode of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Next_Best_Thing_(TV_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Next Best Thing (TV series) (page does not exist)">The Next Best Thing</a></i>.
</li>
<li> In the Emmy Award Winning 2011 miniseries, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Kennedys_(miniseries)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Kennedys (miniseries) (page does not exist)">The Kennedys</a></i>, Sinatra was depicted by Canadian actor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chris_Diamantopoulos&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chris Diamantopoulos (page does not exist)">Chris Diamantopoulos</a>.
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Martin_Scorsese" title="Martin Scorsese">Martin Scorsese</a> is developing a biopic of Sinatra's life to be scripted by <a href="/wiki/Phil_Alden_Robinson" title="Phil Alden Robinson">Phil Alden Robinson</a> and produced by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scott_Rudin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scott Rudin (page does not exist)">Scott Rudin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> When the film was first announced, three actors were said to be in contention for the part: <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_DiCaprio" title="Leonardo DiCaprio">Leonardo DiCaprio</a> was Scorsese's preference, <a href="/wiki/Johnny_Depp" title="Johnny Depp">Johnny Depp</a> was the studio's, and the Sinatra estate preferred <a href="/wiki/George_Clooney" title="George Clooney">George Clooney</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup> Scorsese later mentioned that he wanted <a href="/wiki/Al_Pacino" title="Al Pacino">Al Pacino</a> for Sinatra and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_De_Niro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robert De Niro (page does not exist)">Robert De Niro</a> as Dean Martin.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> The film covers his whole life, so three or more actors will be playing him at different ages.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> Billy Ray has been linked to write the screenplay for the film.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Discography">Discography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards_and_recognitions">Awards and recognitions</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Wikipedia_books&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Wikipedia books (page does not exist)">Template:Wikipedia books</a>

</p>

</li>

</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=File:1930_census_Sinatra_Gavarante.gif&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="File:1930 census Sinatra Gavarante.gif (page does not exist)">1930 US Census</a> with Sinatras

</li>

</li>

</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Frank_Sinatra_Show_(CBS_TV_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Frank Sinatra Show (CBS TV series) (page does not exist)">The Frank Sinatra Show (CBS)</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Frank_Sinatra_Show_(ABC_TV_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Frank Sinatra Show (ABC TV series) (page does not exist)">The Frank Sinatra Show (ABC)</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Anthony_Martin_Sinatra&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anthony Martin Sinatra (page does not exist)">Anthony Martin Sinatra</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Compositions">Compositions</span></h2>
<p>Frank Sinatra co-wrote the following songs in his career:
</p>
<ol>
<li> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=This_Love_of_Mine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="This Love of Mine (page does not exist)">This Love of Mine</a>", released as an RCA Victor 78 B side single in 1941 with <a href="/wiki/Tommy_Dorsey" title="Tommy Dorsey">Tommy Dorsey</a> and his Orchestra.
</li>
<li> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Peachtree_Street_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peachtree Street (song) (page does not exist)">Peachtree Street</a>", released as an A side Columbia single in 1950 as a duet with <a href="/wiki/Rosemary_Clooney" title="Rosemary Clooney">Rosemary Clooney</a>.
</li>
<li> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Take_My_Love_(Frank_Sinatra_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Take My Love (Frank Sinatra song) (page does not exist)">Take My Love</a>", released as a Columbia A side single in 1951.
</li>
<li> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=I%27m_a_Fool_to_Want_You&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I'm a Fool to Want You (page does not exist)">I'm a Fool to Want You</a>", released as a Columbia B side single in 1952.
</li>
<li> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Sheila_(Frank_Sinatra_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sheila (Frank Sinatra song) (page does not exist)">Sheila</a>", released as a Columbia A side single in 1953.
</li>
<li> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Mistletoe_and_Holly&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mistletoe and Holly (page does not exist)">Mistletoe and Holly</a>", released as a Capitol 45 single in 1957.
</li>
<li> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Mr._Success&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mr. Success (page does not exist)">Mr. Success</a>", released as a Capitol A side single in 1958.
</li>
</ol>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biographies">Biographies</span></h3>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=It:Gildo_De_Stefano&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="It:Gildo De Stefano (page does not exist)">De Stefano, Gildo</a>, <i>The Voice – Vita e italianità di Frank Sinatra</i>, Coniglio Press, Roma 2011 <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9788860632593" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 978-88-6063-259-3</a>
</li>
<li>Freedland, Michael (2000) <i>All the Way: A Biography of Frank Sinatra</i>. St Martins Press. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0752816624" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-7528-1662-4</a>
</li>
<li>Grudens, Richard (2010) <i>Sinatra Singing</i>. Celebrity Profiles Publishing. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780976387787" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 978-0-9763877-8-7</a>
</li>
<li>Havers, Richard (2004) <i>Sinatra</i>. Dorling Kindersley. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1405314613" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-4053-1461-3</a>
</li>
<li>Kaplan, James (2010) <i>Frank: The Voice</i>. Doubleday. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780385518048" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 978-0-385-51804-8</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Kitty_Kelley" title="Kitty Kelley">Kelley, Kitty</a> (1986) <i>His Way: The Unauthorized Biography of Frank Sinatra</i>. Bantam Press. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0553265156" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-553-26515-6</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/John_Lahr" title="John Lahr">Lahr, John</a> (1987) <i>Sinatra</i>. Random House. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0753808420" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-7538-0842-0</a>
</li>
<li>Munn, Michael (2002) <i>Sinatra: The Untold Story</i>. Robson Books Ltd. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1861055374" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-86105-537-4</a>
</li>
<li>Rockwell, John (1984) <i>Sinatra: An American Classic</i>. Rolling Stone. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/039453977X" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-394-53977-X</a>
</li>
<li>Rojek, Chris (2004) <i>Frank Sinatra</i>. Polity. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0745630901" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-7456-3090-1</a>
</li>
<li>Santopietro, Tom (2008) <i>Sinatra In Hollywood</i>. Thomas Dunne Books. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780312362263" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 978-0-312-36226-3</a>
</li>
<li>Summers, Antony and Swan, Robbyn (2005) <i>Sinatra: The Life</i>. Doubleday. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0552153311" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-552-15331-1</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=J._Randy_Taraborrelli&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="J. Randy Taraborrelli (page does not exist)">Taraborrelli, J. Randall</a> (1998) <i>Sinatra: The Man Behind the Myth</i>. Mainstream Publishing. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1840181192" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-84018-119-2</a>
</li>
<li>Wilson, Earl (1976) <i>Sinatra</i>.
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Memoirs">Memoirs</span></h3>
<ul>
<li>Ash, Vic. (2006) <i>I Blew it My Way: Bebop, Big Bands and Sinatra</i>. Northway Publications. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0955090822" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-9550908-2-2</a>
</li>
<li>Jacobs, George and Stadiem, William. (2003) <i>Mr. S.: The Last Word on Frank Sinatra</i>. HarperCollins. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0330412299" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-330-41229-9</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Criticism">Criticism</span></h3>
<ul>
<li>Fuchs, J. &amp; Prigozy, R., ed. (2007) <i>Frank Sinatra: The Man, the Music, the Legend</i>. The Boydell Press. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1580462510" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-58046-251-0</a>
</li>
<li>Granata, Charles L. (1999) <i>Sessions with Sinatra: Frank Sinatra and the Art of Recording</i>. Chicago Review Press. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781556525094" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 978-1-55652-509-4</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Pete_Hamill" title="Pete Hamill">Hamill, Pete</a> (2003) <i>Why Sinatra Matters</i>. Back Bay Books. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0316738867" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-316-73886-7</a>
</li>
<li>Mustazza, Leonard, ed. (1998) <i>Frank Sinatra and Popular Culture</i>. Praeger. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0275964957" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-275-96495-7</a>
</li>
<li>Petkov, Steven and Mustazza, Leonard, ed. (1997) <i>The Frank Sinatra Reader</i>. Oxford University Press. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0195113896" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-19-511389-6</a>
</li>
<li>Pugliese, S., ed. (2004) <i>Frank Sinatra: "History, Identity, and Italian American Culture "</i>. Palgrave. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1403966559" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-4039-6655-9</a>
</li>
<li>Smith, Martin (2005) <i>When Ol' Blue Eyes Was a Red</i>. Redwords. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1905192029" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-905192-02-9</a>
</li>
<li>Zehme, Bill (1997) <i>The Way You Wear Your Hat: Frank Sinatra and the Lost Art of Livin'</i>. Harper Collins. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0060931752" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-06-093175-2</a>
</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jazzsingers.com/FrankSinatra/">"Frank Sinatra – Through the Lens of Jazz"</a>, <i>Jazz Times Magazine</i>, May 1998
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Will_Friedwald&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Will Friedwald (page does not exist)">Friedwald, Will</a> (1999) <i>Sinatra! The Song Is You: A Singer's Art</i>. Da Capo Press. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/068419368X" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-684-19368-X</a>
</li>
<li>Granata, Charles L. (1999) <i>Sessions with Sinatra: Frank Sinatra and the Art of Recording</i>. Chicago Review Press. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1556525095" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-55652-509-5</a>
</li>
<li>McNally, Karen (2008) <i>When Frankie Went to Hollywood: Frank Sinatra and American Male Identity</i> University of Illinois Press. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0252033345" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-252-03334-5</a>
</li>
<li>Pignone, Charles, with foreword by <a href="/wiki/Frank_Sinatra,_Jr." title="Frank Sinatra, Jr.">Sinatra, Frank Jr</a>. and <a href="/wiki/Quincy_Jones" title="Quincy Jones">Jones, Quincy</a> (2004) <i>The Sinatra Treasures</i>. Virgin Books. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1852271841" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-85227-184-1</a>
</li>
<li>Pignone, Charles, with foreword by Sinatra, Amanda (2007) <i>Frank Sinatra: The Family Album </i> Little Brown and Company. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0316003492" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-316-00349-2</a>
</li>
<li>Sinatra, Julie (2007) <i>Under My Skin: My Father, Frank Sinatra The Man Behind the Mystique</i> iuniverse.com, <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0595434789" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-595-43478-9</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Nancy_Sinatra" title="Nancy Sinatra">Sinatra, Nancy</a> (1986) <i>Frank Sinatra, My Father</i>. Doubleday. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780385233569" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 978-0-385-23356-9</a>
</li>
<li>Sinatra, Nancy (1998) <i>Frank Sinatra 1915–1998: An American Legend</i>. Readers Digest. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0762101342" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-7621-0134-2</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tina_Sinatra" title="Tina Sinatra">Sinatra, Tina</a> (2000) <i>My Father's Daughter</i>. Simon &amp; Schuster. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0684870762" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-684-87076-2</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cultural_criticism">Cultural criticism</span></h3>
<ul>
<li>Gigliotti, Gilbert L. <i>A Storied Singer: Frank Sinatra as Literary Conceit</i>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenwood_Publishing_Group&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenwood Publishing Group (page does not exist)">Greenwood Press</a>, 2002.
</li>
<li>Hamill, Pete. <i>Why Sinatra Matters</i>. Back Bay Books, 2003.
</li>
<li>Mustazza, Leonard, ed. <i>Frank Sinatra and Popular Culture</i>. Praeger, 1998.
</li>
<li>Petkov, Steven and Mustazza, Leonard, ed. <i>The Frank Sinatra Reader</i>. Oxford University Press, 1997.
</li>
<li>Pugliese, S., ed. <i>Frank Sinatra: "History, Identity, and Italian American Culture "</i>. Palgrave, 2004.
</li>
<li>Smith, Martin. <i>When Ol' Blue Eyes was a red</i>. Redwords, 2005.
</li>
<li>Zehme, Bill. <i>The Way You Wear Your Hat: Frank Sinatra and the Lost Art of Livin'</i>. Harper Collins, 1997.
</li>
</ul>

<ul>

</li>
<li>Giordmaina, Diane [McCue] (2009) "Sinatra and The Moll". iUniverse. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780595532346" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 978-0-595-53234-6</a>
</li>
<li>Havers, Richard (2004) <i>Sinatra</i>. Dorling Kindersley. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1405314613" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-4053-1461-3</a>
</li>
<li>Ingham, Chris (2005) <i>The Rough Guide to Frank Sinatra</i>. Rough Guides. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1843534142" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-84353-414-2</a>
</li>
<li>Knight, Timothy (2010) <i>Sinatra – Hollywood His Way</i>. Running Press. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780762437436" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 978-0-7624-3743-6</a>
</li>
<li>Kuntz, Tom; Kuntz, Phil (2000) <i>The Sinatra Files: The Secret FBI Dossier</i>. Three Rivers Press <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0812932765" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-8129-3276-5</a>
</li>
<li>Lloyd, David (2003) <i>The Gospel According to Frank</i>. New American Press. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1930907192" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-930907-19-2</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Terry_O%27Neill_(photographer)" title="Terry O'Neill (photographer)">O'Neill, Terry</a>, ed. Morgan, Robert (2007) <i>Sinatra: Frank and Friendly</i>. Evans Mitchell Books. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1901268322" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-901268-32-2</a>
</li>
<li>Phasey, Chris (1995) <i>Francis Albert Sinatra: Tracked Down</i> (Discography). Buckland Publications. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0721209351" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-7212-0935-1</a>
</li>
<li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rolling_Stone_Record_Guide&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rolling Stone Record Guide (page does not exist)">The New Rolling Stone Record Guide</a></i>, Rolling Stone Press, 1983.
</li>
</ul>
